editorialDecl.p: EEBO-TCP is a partnership between the Universities of Michigan and Oxford and the publisher ProQuest to create accurately transcribed and encoded texts based on the image sets published by ProQuest via their Early English Books Online (EEBO) database (http://eebo.chadwyck.com). The general aim of EEBO-TCP is to encode one copy (usually the first edition) of every monographic English-language title published between 1473 and 1700 available in EEBO.

EEBO-TCP aimed to produce large quantities of textual data within the usual project restraints of time and funding, and therefore chose to create diplomatic transcriptions (as opposed to critical editions) with light-touch, mainly structural encoding based on the Text Encoding Initiative (http://www.tei-c.org).

The EEBO-TCP project was divided into two phases. The 25,368 texts created during Phase 1 of the project (2000-2009), initially available only to institutions that contributed to their creation, were released into the public domain on 1 January 2015. The approximately 40,000 texts produced during Phase 2 (2009- ), of which 34,963 had been released as of 2020, originally similarly restricted, were similarly freed from all restrictions on 1 August 2020. As of that date anyone is free to take and use these texts for any purpose (modify them, annotate them, distribute them, etc.). But we do respectfully request that due credit and attribution be given to their original source.
Users should be aware of the process of creating the TCP texts, and therefore of any assumptions that can be made about the data.

Text selection was based on the New Cambridge Bibliography of English Literature (NCBEL). If an author (or for an anonymous work, the title) appears in NCBEL, then their works are eligible for inclusion. Selection was intended to range over a wide variety of subject areas, to reflect the true nature of the print record of the period. In general, first editions of a works in English were prioritized, although there are a number of works in other languages, notably Latin and Welsh, included and sometimes a second or later edition of a work was chosen if there was a compelling reason to do so.

Image sets were sent to external keying companies for transcription and basic encoding. Quality assurance was then carried out by editorial teams in Oxford and Michigan. 5% (or 5 pages, whichever is the greater) of each text was proofread for accuracy and those which did not meet QA standards were returned to the keyers to be redone. After proofreading, the encoding was enhanced and/or corrected and characters marked as illegible were corrected where possible up to a limit of 100 instances per text. Any remaining illegibles were encoded as <gap>s. Understanding these processes should make clear that, while the overall quality of TCP data is very good, some errors will remain and some readable characters will be marked as illegible. Users should bear in mind that in all likelihood such instances will never have been looked at by a TCP editor.
The texts were encoded and linked to page images in accordance with level 4 of the TEI in Libraries guidelines.

Copies of the texts have been issued variously as SGML (TCP schema; ASCII text with mnemonic sdata character entities); displayable XML (TCP schema; characters represented either as UTF-8 Unicode or text strings within braces); or lossless XML (TEI P5, characters represented either as UTF-8 Unicode or TEI g elements).
Keying and markup guidelines are available at the Text Creation Partnership web site.

div.p: THE WALKS OF ISLINGTON and HOGSDON, WITH The Humours of Woodſtreet-Compter.
A Comedy, As it was publikely Acted 19. days together, with extraordinary Applauſe.
div.q: Carpere vel noli noſtra, vel ede tua, Mart. Epig.
div.p: LONDON: Printed by Tho. Wilſon at the ſign of the Three-Foxes in Long-lane. 1657.

div.head: TO The true Lover of Ingenuitie, The much Honoured, RICHARD CHEYNEY, of Hackney, Eſquire.
div.p: IN thoſe jocund dayes, when ingenious Spirits were not daunted to behold the Phyſiognomy of their Minds and Manners in the Mirrour of a Dramatick-Poem, this Comedy gained the ſucceſs of a good Cenſure, and received more Acceptation then I thought it merited: Yet ſince the importunacy of Friends hath prevailed with me (in this tempeſtuous ſeaſon) to print it; Prudence hath well inſtructed me to ſhrowd it under the undoubted ſafety of your Protection; becauſe I am aſſured that the glittering influence of your bright Approbation, will, as the riſing Sun doth gild all Trees he looks upon, ſet ſuch a luſtre on theſe Leaves, that Time armed with Envie ſhall never extinguiſh; ſuch lawful confidence hath he aſſumed that wiſheth your everlaſting proſperity, and deſireth no other temporal Title, then to be found in the Liſt, though the leaſt of,

list.item: Flylove, A Humoriſt, Lover to Bellaflora.
Rivers. Love and brother to Mrs. Trimwel.
Wildblood. A Companion to Flylove, and nephew to Bella.
Sir Reverence Lamard, Brother to Splendora, diſguis'd like a Frenchman.
Pimpwel, A creature to the young Gallants.
Mr. Trimwel, An old jealou Citizen.
Two Serjeants. The one of them Tripes.

list.head: Women.
list.item: Mrs. Trimwel, A Citizens wife, and ſiſter to Rivers. Miſtris of the Kings-head at Hogsdon.

div.head: To his much deſerving Friend Mr. Thomas Jordan, on his excellent Comedy, entituled, The Walks of Iſlington and Hogsdon, With the Humours of Woodſtreet-Compter.
div.l: HOw have I task'd my ſelf that now muſt clear
A debt that's due almoſt this twenty year?
And, by your large improvements ſince, do finde
You much before, and my ſelf caſt behinde,
In ſuch a weak condition, who can
Expect full payment from a Bankerupt man?
Yet know no empty ſhaddows had the Art,
To catch my prayſes, but your known deſart;
Though love obligeth love, the nobler tye
Of worth by knowledge is mere faſt and high;
With Poetry you have Muſick, and as ſoon
As you have made the Song, you ſet the Tune;
Where both in meaſure ſo exactly dance,
Numbers court Numbers, Ayrs do Words advance;
Had I but room, I could declare how clean
Your Fancy wrought, which did adorn your Scaene
In ſeveral Plots, and Plays, this here exprest,
Will ſpeak the noble Linage of the reſt.
Theſe Walks 'twixt Iſlington and Hogsdon will,
(Like thoſe 'twixt Tempe and Parnaſſus Hill)
Show how the Muſes in their ſportfull rage,
Set all the Town a Walking to your Stage,
With ſo much Wit, and Art, and Judgement lay'd,
That nineteen days together they were play'd.
Now by the bounty of the Preſs we be
Poſſeſs'd of that which we before did ſee,
Not pleaſing onely nineteen times read o're,
But nineteen Ages, or till Time's no more.

div.head: The Prologue.
div.l: THe Author (as late cuſtome hath thought fit)
Makes me the Prologue to his wandring Wit;
The Gate into his Walks, through which you may
Behold a petty proſpect of the Play;
A Play of Walks, or you may pleaſe to rank it,
With that which Ladies love, A running Banquet:
And, though the Scoene be Iſlington, we ſwear,
We will not blow ye up with Bottle Bear;
Cram ye with Cream and Fools, which ſweetly pleaſe
Ladies of Fortune and young Prentices,
Who (when the Superviſors come to find 'um)
Quake like the Cuſtard which they leave behind 'um.
Yet to exalt your ſpleen, he hath invented,
Perſons that you'l all know when they'r preſented;
Nay they ſhall know themſelvs, and that is more,
It may be then you ever knew before.
We'l ſhew you things not taken out of Hiſt'ries,
A loyal Lover, and a grateful Miſtriſs,
A futile Frenchman (acted to the life)
A jealous husband and a jocund wife,
That kiſſeth, danceth, tipples like a Tench,
A Chamber-Gallant and a Kitchin-wench;
A jovial Cobler (or a Quibler rather)
A Catchpole that arreſted his own father;
A crew of Ranters to the Gaole committed,
A dead man rais'd, a Uſurer out-witted,
A Priſon-Pimp diſcover'd and detected,
The Compter character'd, the Hole diſſected.
Here my Commiſſion ends, leſt I betray
The Plot, and ſhew the Clock-work of the I lay:
Your liking will (like to the Suns bright rays)
Lighten the Gaole, and plant theſe Walks with Bays,
Where you will finde ſome Flowers as well as ſtalks,
Then lend's your hands, we'l lead you to the Walks,

div.head: The Walks of Iſlington and Hogsdon, &c.
Actus primus, Scoena prima.
div.stage: Enter as at the Sarazens-head in Iſlington; Jack Wildblood, Frank Rivers, and Stephen Flylove; to them Tavern-Boyes.

sp.speaker: Wildblood.
sp.p: BOy Drawer.

sp.speaker: Rivers.
sp.p: Drawer, Sirrah.

sp.speaker: Within.
sp.p: By and by, anon, anon Sir.

sp.speaker: Wildbl.
sp.l: Why thou Parte-per-villain,
Drawer and Tapſter,
Are you ſo taken up with your Holyday Gheſts,
A Gentleman can have no attendance?

sp.speaker: Drawer.
sp.p: Attendance? Yes Sir, What Wine will it pleaſe you to drink?

sp.speaker: Rivers.
sp.p: That is, which of three ſorts will ye drink, Sack, White, or Claret.

sp.speaker: Draw.
sp.p: Nay (with your favour Sir) we have more variety then thoſe.

sp.speaker: lylove.
sp.p: Well then Sir, without farther diſputation, bring White Wine, and let it be right.

sp.speaker: Drawer.
sp.p: I ſhall Sir.

sp.speaker: Wild.
sp.p: Well Frank, and how doth thy little Miſtris?

sp.speaker: Rivers.
sp.p: What little Miſtris?

sp.speaker: Wild.
sp.p: Why ſhe that is the rareſt, the faireſt that ever was Maid, Jack Trimwel the Chyrurgeons wife.

sp.speaker: Rivers.
sp.p: Mum, not a word, our plots are almoſt diſcovered, I have kept ſome villains company that have betray'd me to the jealous Coxcomb (her husband) ſhe'l be here preſently.

sp.speaker: Wild.
sp.p: Who haſt ſent?

sp.speaker: Rivers.
sp.p: My old Mercury, Alexander Pimpwel.

sp.speaker: Fly.
sp.l: Look, you can no ſooner talk of Pimpwel,
But the Drawer comes; ſirrah, have you any
Whores in the houſe?

sp.speaker: Drawer.
sp.p: I cannot tell Sir, I'le ask the Fidlers.

sp.speaker: Fly.
sp.p: Hark you ſirrah, have you any females in the houſe?

sp.speaker: Draw.
sp.p: Yes Sir, there's half a ſcore in ſeveral rooms.

sp.speaker: Fly.
sp.l: Why you rogue, do you doubt whether there be
Any whores in the houſe then?

sp.speaker: Rivers.
sp.p: Why thou rebel to Chaſtity, doſt thou conceive the ſtock of Females vertue is ſo extreamly waſted, that in ſo ſmall a number as they are, the moſt part muſt be vitious?

sp.speaker: Fly.
sp.p: I, I vow if there were but two there, though my Mother were one.

sp.speaker: Wild.
sp.p: And thy Aunt tother.

sp.speaker: Fly.
sp.p: I mean ſo, the other ſhould be one of my Aunts.

div.stage: Enter Alexander Pimpwel and Mrs. Trimwel.

sp.speaker: Rivers.
sp.p: Little Betty, your humble ſervant.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Trim.
sp.p: But hark you Frank, what Gentlemen are theſe?

sp.speaker: Riv.
sp.p: Friends of mine, moſt dear and intimate, ſalute them.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Trim.
sp.p: Oh, y' are a pretty Gentleman to ſend for me into company.

sp.speaker: Wild.
sp.p: Lady your humble ſervant.

sp.speaker: Flyl.
sp.p: Turn to me hony, and give me a kiſs.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Trim.
sp.p: Turn to you Sir, which part? my face is towards you already.

sp.speaker: Fly.
sp.p: By the Cherry-lip of Venus, you are wondrous witty, Lady.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Trim.
sp.p: I am glad Sir you ſo apprehend it.

sp.speaker: Fly.
sp.p: 'Tis not my apprehenſion can mend it.

sp.speaker: Rivers.
sp.p: Is ſhe not wondrous fair?

sp.speaker: Fly.
sp.l: I dare not tell you,
For ſhould I grow ſo paſſionate in praiſe
As her worth merits, I might juſtly fear
Your fondneſs of her would ſuſpect my friendſhip;
For in this age Experience makes it common,
He needs muſt love that doth but praiſe a woman.

sp.speaker: Rivers.
sp.l: You wrong my friendſhip to ſuppoſe I doubt you.
It were an injury to her and you;
The baſe ſuſpect from neither is exempted,
To think that you ſhould tempt, or ſhe be tempted.

sp.speaker: Wild.
sp.l: You are full of Noble confidence, I think ſhe
Loves you well.

sp.speaker: Rivers.
sp.l: Or ſhe doth well diſſemble,
But here's the wo, what bondage is he in,
That lives in love, when all his love is ſin?

sp.speaker: Mrs. Trim.
sp.l: Gentlemen, doth my coming cauſe this diviſion among you?
Such ſeperation in ſo few a number hath been unuſuall.

sp.speaker: Wild.
sp.l: Your coming Lady rather makes an unitie,
Frank Rivers I'le begin a round to thy Miſtris.

sp.speaker: Rivers.
sp.p: Let it come.

sp.speaker: Fly.
sp.p: I vow I'le pledg't a brimmer:

l.hi: My Miſtris hath a Roſie Check

stage.l: For tis a Health to Betty.

sp.speaker: Draw:
sp.p: Mr. Flylove is your name I pray Sir.

sp.speaker: Fly.
sp.p: Yes, ſo they ſay Sir.

sp.speaker: Draw.
sp.p: There's a woman without would ſpeak with you.

sp.speaker: Fly.
sp.p: Prethee what manner of piece is it?

sp.speaker: Draw.
sp.l: A good homely creature Sir, ſome ſervant I believe,
A Maid-ſervant I dare ſwear ſhe is not,
For her noſe and belly do almoſt meet.

sp.speaker: Fly.
sp.p: A ſtrange creature, either ſhe hath a very aſide. long noſe, or a terrible great belly, and now I talk of a great belly, I pray Heaven it be not the Kitchin-wench I was dabling withall once, when drink and a fooliſh humor poſſeſt me (I heard ſhe was with Child) if it be, Exit Drawer. I am undone for ever, ſtay I'le go out to her.

sp.speaker: Drowzy.
sp.p: No Sir, ſhe I come in to you.

sp.speaker: Fly.
sp.p: Prethee honeſt Drowzy.

sp.speaker: Drow.
sp.p: Honeſt Drowzy I, I was honeſt Drowzy before I knew you.

sp.speaker: Fly.
sp.l: Nay but prethee Drowzy that was once honeſt,
Let me ſpeak with thee in private.

sp.speaker: Drow.
sp.p: No Sir, you have ſpoken too much in private with me already, Ecce ſigne, and Jle ſpeak to you here Sir; for all your fine Laſs there in the ſilk, I might have been as fine as ſhe, and yaw had kept your word.

sp.speaker: Wild.
sp.p: How now Stephen, what's the matter?

sp.speaker: Drow.
sp.l: What's that to yaw ſir,
Pray meddle with your own buſineſs.

sp.speaker: Fly.
sp.p: Prethee be gone Jack, 'tis an honeſt Laſs comes with an errand to me.

sp.speaker: Drow.
sp.p: An arrant, what arrant am I, I come to ſpeak to you Sir, and to have ſatisfaction for the wrong you have done me, ye ſhall nere carry it to heaven nor to hell.

sp.speaker: Fly.
sp.l: What the Devil ſhall I do, Drawer?
Prethee what haſt thou brought me here, a mad wench?

sp.speaker: Drow.
sp.p: What would you have ſirrah?
sp.stage: Gives the Boy a box oth' eare.

sp.speaker: Draw.
sp.l: A pox o' your greaſie fingers,
An you were not with Child —
— If ſhe be mad, I pray Sir do you tame her.

sp.speaker: Rivers.
sp.p: How now Stephen, what's the buſineſs?

sp.speaker: Drow.
sp.p: What care yaw ſir, you may go to yawr Gentlewoman in the long locks again.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Trim.
sp.p: What is the woman mad?

sp.speaker: Drow.
sp.p: Mad! no ſhe's as wel in her wits as you are, though ſhe is not ſo fine forſooth.

sp.speaker: Pimpw.
sp.p: Mrs. Trimwell, as I live your Husband's here.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Trim.
sp.p: Marry Heaven defend.

sp.speaker: Pimpw.
sp.p: He's coming up ſtayrs.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Trim.
sp.p: What will become on's.

sp.speaker: Pimpw.
sp.p:
There's but one way, and thats this, here is a door goes down another pair of ſtayrs, whilſt he comes up, do you
run down, you may eaſily eſcape unſeen by the back-ſide of Iſlington. Let me alone here.

sp.speaker: Fly.
sp.p: I, I, come let's go, I think the devil haunts us to day.

sp.speaker: Drow.
sp.l: Pray whither go yaw ſir,
I ha' more to ſay to you then ſo.

sp.speaker: Fly.
sp.p: Prethee honeſt Pimpwel keep this mad wench from me, and do you pay the reckning, you know our old rendezvouz.

sp.speaker: Pimpw.
sp.p: Well, well, let me alone.
sp.stage: Exeunt Wildblood Mrs. Trim. & Flylove, manent Pimpw. with Drowzy.

sp.speaker: Drow.
sp.p: Keep me back! ſirrah Ile ſet all my fingers in your eyes, if you keep me back, though your name be Pimpw. you ſhal not keep the door at this time.

sp.speaker: Trimw.
sp.p: How now what's the matter? vaniſhed, ha all vaniſhed, only one rogue and a dirty whore, what are you, what are you, pray turn about?

sp.speaker: Drow.
sp.p: Dirty whore, you lye like a baſe rogue, I am as honeſt a woman as thy wife, what come you for?

sp.speaker: Trim.
sp.p: As honeſt as my wife, I, I, it may be ſo good Porpus, I ſpeak not to you, pray Sir where is all your company gone, where's my wife.

sp.speaker: Pimpw.
sp.p: Your wife Sir.

sp.speaker: Trim.
sp.p: My wife Sir, I my wife Sir.

sp.speaker: Drow.
sp.p: Doſt thou call me Porpus, you may be aſhamed to liken a woman to a beaſt, I am as like a Chriſtian as thou art, or any of thy kin, my father was as honeſt a man as any in Warwickshire, and his daughter ſhall not be made a fool yet as.

sp.speaker: Trim.
sp.p: Wher's my wife? what ſecret holes have you?

sp.speaker: Pimpw.
sp.p: What do you ask me for your wife Sir, I know her not, nor you?

sp.speaker: Draw.
sp.p: Anon, anon Sir, by and by, did you call? how now what's become of the company was here, who payes the Reckoning?

sp.speaker: Trim.
sp.p: Hey day, what have they left their Reckoning to pay, they were in mighty haſt it ſeems?

sp.speaker: Drow.
sp.p: Was the woman in the black Guown yawr woife Sir?

sp.speaker: Trim.
sp.p: Yes, which way went they?

sp.speaker: Drow.
sp.l: Marry 3. Gentlemen carried her down them ſtayrs,
You were beſt make haſte after 'um, or they'l
Make you a Coock old afore you come, and then
You'l loſe the ſport.

sp.speaker: Trim.
sp.l: He follow preſently, I gueſs where to find them.
If I cannot overtake them.

sp.speaker: Drow.
sp.l: By the maſſe Ile follow too, for my Gentleman
Is amongſt them; Ile teach him to turne
Up wenches bellies, and give them no ſartifaction.

sp.speaker: Pimp.
sp.p: Well you have your reckoning Drawer.

sp.speaker: Draw.
sp.l: To a farthing Sir, if you'l ſtay Sir, Ile give
You one pinte, becauſe you ſhall remember the
Sarazens head in Iſlington.

sp.speaker: Pimp.
sp.l: I cannot ſtay now, I faith ſirrah, but next time
I come this way.

sp.speaker: Draw.
sp.p: Well Sir, you are welcome, by and by, I come, I come.

sp.speaker: Pimpw.
sp.p: So, ſo, a bad ſhift's better then none; oh the rage his head is filld with for his wife, and the belly full of vexation ſhe has to find Mr. Flylove. Pox of all fooles, I wonder what mad folly poſſes'd him to lye with this dirty, greaſy kichen-wench, was his appetite ſo ſharp ſet, that he muſt needs be lapping in the Dripping-pan? well, Ile follow them; I know their old haunt (the Kings-head at Hogſdown) Jealouſie hath many eyes, I muſt prevent the ſearcher: If all my plots hit right, Ile make the Cuckolds horns hang in his light.

sp.speaker: Mercu.
sp.l: My fair Splendora, though my fortunes are,
Humble as he that ownes them; yet I can
Love thee with holy ardencie; devoutly
As zealous men in prayer do their Saints,
Or Votaries their Goddeſs.

sp.speaker: Splend.
sp.l: I know you want not wit to coyn a paſſion,
And pray (with all Mercurio) conceive,
I know how many ſymtoms of true love,
A Paraſite (in ſervice to his Mrs.)
Can uſe to gain his end; 'tis not a ſigh,
Diſſembled ſorrow in a far ſtraind tear,
The folded Arms; Encomiums compos'd,
With many interjections, nor the trick,
Of praiſing what ſhe's pleaſed with, can move me
To the leaſt faith, he whoſe ſlow tongue ſpeaks leaſt,
In Love or ſorrow oftentimes means beſt.

sp.speaker: Merc.
sp.l: I am ſorry you ſhould think I doubt your knowlege
I know you have a ſoul as full of Raies,
As Delphean Phaebus in oraculous glory;
You have divinity enough to ſee,
The pureſt love from niceſt flattery,
Or I ſhould ne'r affect you, tis my thought,
That ſhe whom flattery can purchaſe to me,
By one more ſubtil may be flattered fro me.

sp.speaker: Splend.
sp.l: You give a large account of your pure thoughts,
And I beleeve thee with ſuch confidence,
As to not do't, were hereſie; There
Reſign thee all the intreſt I hold dear,
In this weak frame.

sp.speaker: Merc.
sp.l: That ſhall contain us both,
Our hearts ſhall be one individuall eſſence,
To which we'l frame like paſſions, like affections,
By this divineſt Metomorphoſis,
The Gods (well pleas'd) ſhall terminate our lives,
Both at one Expiration in good age,
Seaſon'd and fit for glory, more Divine,
Where in one or be our unity ſhall ſhine.

sp.speaker: Nice.
sp.l: Who's here (undone) Mercurio and my daughter
Embracing? Changes Kiſſes? I ſhall part you.

sp.speaker: Splend.
sp.p: My Father.

sp.speaker: Nice.
sp.p: Splendora, your Mother calls you.

sp.speaker: Splend.
sp.l: I am ſorry Sir I have ſuch faulty ears, as not
To hear till your love pleaſe to tell me,
I attend her.

sp.speaker: Nice.
sp.p: Sir tis to you that I direct my ſpeech.

sp.speaker: Merc.
sp.p: I ſhall attend Sir what your ſpeech directs.

sp.speaker: Nice.
sp.l: To this intent I frame it, whats the cauſe
You make it all the buſineſs of your time
In viſits to my houſe? though uninvited,
I do not ſay you'r an unwelcome gueſt,
But till I know the motive of your coming,
I ſhall be cautious in your entertainment.

sp.speaker: Merc.
sp.l: Your words do bear a ſtrange ſuſpect in them,
And this to me, the Son of him that was
Once your beſt friend; whoſe love hath made you rich,
The manner's ſomewhat ſtrange.

sp.speaker: Nice.
sp.l: I ſhall be plainer,
I diſaffect your neerneſs with my daughter,
I have beheld looſe kiſſes fond embraces,
Her ſighes to eccho yours, ſuch wantonneſs
As may not fit a pair of ſingle creatures,
Much leſſe you two, conſidering the diſtance.
Sir to be brief, I do ſuſpect you love her.

sp.speaker: Merc.
sp.p: Oh nere ſuſpect ſo Sir, you may be ſure on't.

sp.speaker: Splend.
sp.p: Why this is honeſt truth, fine right down dealing.

sp.speaker: Nice.
sp.p: And ſhe loves you.

sp.speaker: Merc.
sp.p: I hope ſhe will in time Sir.

sp.speaker: Nice.
sp.p: Tis well Sir, lend me your eare.

sp.speaker: Merc.
sp.p: Your pleaſure.

sp.speaker: Splend.
sp.l: I fear this whiſpering portends no good,
Here's pen and paper, Ile appoint our meeting,
Though we ſhall miſſe that ceremonious way,
Of lovely parting we were wont to have,
Ile find occaſion to deliver this.

sp.speaker: Nice.
sp.p: Nay which is more, you are a riotous man.

sp.speaker: Nice.
sp.l: And let me tell you Sir, my Child and wealth,
Shall not be both expoſ'd to your profuſeneſs
Therefore (by my admoniſhment) pray leave her.

sp.speaker: Merc.
sp.p: Sir did you ever love?

sp.speaker: Nice.
sp.p: Yes.

sp.speaker: Merc.
sp.p: But did you e're affect a Virgin truly?

sp.speaker: Nice.
sp.p: As man can do.

sp.speaker: Merc.
sp.p: When.

sp.speaker: Nice.
sp.l: When time and love had made me capable
Of woman and her vertues.

p.hi: In the green long walk by Newington.

sp.speaker: Merc.
sp.l: Was not her preſence all your heaven on earth,
And then her abſence brought ſuch ſickly thoughts,
No novelty could mitigate.

sp.speaker: Nice.
sp.p: Very true.

sp.speaker: Merc.
sp.l: With that affection I eſteem your daughter.
Juſt ſuch a heaven her bleſt ſociety,
And ſuch a hell her abſence, had we not
By ſome diviner inſpiration,
A little proſpect to eternity,
I ſhould believe all joyes of ſoul were her:
The moſt indulgent Mothers never lov'd,
Their fair ligitimate Babes with ſuch a fondneſs,
As I do your Splendora.

sp.speaker: Nice.
sp.p: You are very bountifull in your expreſſion.

sp.speaker: Merc.
sp.l: Too niggardly, her goodneſs merits more
Then I have worth to know, or tongue to utter;
I think her vertues all are infinite,
And not to be examin'd, I have ſearcht,
With moſt ingenious and induſtrious boldneſs,
To take the height of her perfection,
But forc'd with admiration to retire,
For ſtill as I drew neer her ſoul flew higher.

sp.speaker: Nice.
sp.l: You have expreſt her merit and your love,
And had you an eſtate equall to either,
With worldly providence and care to uſe it,
I ſhould eſteem your motion, as you are;
Your polyte phraſes cannot work on me,
Nor ſhall they on my daughter, whoſe obedience
Muſt be conformable to my diſpoſe.

sp.speaker: Splend.
sp.p: Did you call Sir.

sp.speaker: Nice.
sp.l: No,
But ſince your diligence hath got ſuch wings,
Stay and take leave of your kind viſitant,
And be not tedious.

sp.speaker: Splend.
sp.p: Well Sir.

sp.speaker: Nice.
sp.l: I have ſome buſines may concern your good,
Which you cannot conceive.

sp.speaker: Splend.
sp.l: I do believe you.
You ſee my dear Mercurio, how adverſe
My Father is, time's ſhort, read that, farewell,
We'l meet agen.

sp.speaker: Merc.
sp.p: This parting is my hell.

sp.speaker: Servant.
sp.p: Sir the French Knight is come,

sp.speaker: Nice.
sp.p: Wait on him in.

sp.speaker: Ser.
sp.p: I ſhall Sir.

sp.speaker: Splend.
sp.p: Oh, my torment!
sp.stage: Enter Sir Reverence and Wildfire his Page.

sp.speaker: Nice.
sp.p: Noble Sir Reverence, your humble ſervant.

sp.speaker: Sir Rev.
sp.l: Tres humble Serviture Monſieur.
A voſtre Serviture Madam.

sp.speaker: Nice.
sp.l: Sir you too ſeldome grace us with your viſits,
Although our country cuſtome cannot yield,
That fair and ceremonious entertainment
You French men uſe; believe me you are welcome.

sp.speaker: Sir Rev.
sp.l: Gramercie Monſieur de mon ceuir,
Vat you name de Madam your dater a.

sp.speaker: Nice.
sp.p: We call her Sir Splendora.

sp.speaker: Sir Rev.
sp.p: Spent whora?

sp.speaker: Sir Rev.
sp.p: Split whore a.

sp.speaker: Nice.
sp.p: The name is ſome what hard Sir.

sp.speaker: Sir Rev.
sp.p: Begar ſo it is, Split, Split, Split whore a.

sp.speaker: Nice.
sp.p: Do.

sp.speaker: Sir Rev.
sp.p: Do.

sp.speaker: Nice.
sp.p: Right Sir.

sp.speaker: Sir Rev.
sp.p: Madam Splen do ra, will you give Sir Reverence, Leave to kiſſe beſhide your ſheeke.

sp.speaker: Splend.
sp.p: Let it be but of one ſide I beſeech you Sir, I have lately been troubled with the Tooth-ake.

sp.speaker: Nice.
sp.p: Ile leave you ſir to opportunity.

sp.speaker: Sir Rev.
sp.p: Gramercie Monſeir, voſtre ſerviteur.

sp.speaker: Wild.
sp.p: At your backe Monſeir.

sp.speaker: Sir Rev.
sp.p: Allo allo.

sp.speaker: Wild.
sp.p: I am gon Sir.

sp.speaker: Sir Rev.
sp.p: Madam your fadra ſay to me he would have me take you for my wife, my Lady, my Madam, my Madam Lamard;

sp.speaker: Splend.
sp.p: Did my father bid you put me in hope of theſe phantaſticke titles?

sp.speaker: Sir Rev.
sp.p: Fantaſie, begar be brave title to be wife to Sir Reverence Lamard.

sp.speaker: Splend.
sp.p: To be your wife Sir Reverence?

sp.speaker: Sir Rev.
sp.p: Awee, and Sir Reverence to be your husband.

sp.speaker: Splend.
sp.l: I thank you Sir.
I hope that uinon will happy prove;
Where Sir Reverence is the beginning of love,

sp.speaker: Sir Rev.
sp.p: Begar dat was right, me love you out of all cry, You ſhall be a Lady, when we have marry, wee'l go to Parry, begar was de brave City of the World, me will have you dreſſe like de Frenſh Madam, and ride in your Carroſh, begar dis Engliſh Dreſſe is noting; 'tis not a le mode France, den me vill ſhew you de brave Pallace of de King, you never ſee ſuch ſtate in your life, Oh brava, brava; and den.

sp.speaker: Splend.
sp.l: Pray ſtay there Sir.
I wonder that a Knight of your vaſt wealth,
In your owne Country could not find a faire one,
Worthy to meet your merrit; I may doubt
You are not what you would have me conceive,
Or my too credulous father is inform'd,
And did your judgment, ſympathize with mine,
I would not wiſh you to adventure marriage,
With any Lady of another Nation,
There is a fitneſs to be found in love,
Which very far tranſcends wealth wit or beauty,
By him that keeps me for a better end,
I would not be your Miſtris, could you give,
All Paris, for Joynture; The truth is I am engaged.

sp.speaker: Sir Rev.
sp.p: Begar den you ſhall be no Lady.

sp.speaker: Splend.
sp.p: I ſhall be contented with my fortune.
sp.stage: Enter to them Nice and Wildfire.

sp.speaker: Nice.
sp.p: How is't Sir Reverence, what is my daughter plyant,

sp.speaker: Sir Rev.
sp.p: Begar your dauter ſay ſhe will no have me, if I Shall give all Pary for a zhoynture.

sp.speaker: Nice.
sp.l: You muſt give Virgins licenſe to be Nice,
Things eaſily purchaſed are not valuable,
Is it their own worth or their ſcarcity,
That ſets ſo high a price on Jewells think you.

sp.speaker: Sir Rev.
sp.p: Begar your dauter be fooliſh to ſlight me, She bid me love de frenſh Lady, begar ſo me can.

sp.speaker: Nice.
sp.p: I hope ſhe hath not angerd you Sir Reverence.

sp.speaker: Sir Rev.
sp.p: Begar is vill know me can have de brave Lady in France.

sp.speaker: Nice.
sp.p: I do not queſtion't Sir, ſhe is too peeviſh.

sp.speaker: Sir Re.
sp.l: Begar me have ſcorn a Counteſſe in France, and
Have had two three love letter from a Douſheſſe,
Since I came to Englant, your dauter no know
Vat J am, ſhe be foole beggar — Vildfire.

sp.speaker: Wild.
sp.p: Monſieur.

sp.speaker: Sir Re.
sp.p: Donne moy me manteau.

sp.speaker: Wild.
sp.p: Awy Monſieur voſtre ſervice.

sp.speaker: Nice.
sp.p: I hope you will not leave us ſo Sir.

sp.speaker: Sir Re.
sp.p: Begar me vill ſtay no longer your dauter a ſcorn my love.

sp.speaker: Nice.
sp.p: Be not ſo diſcontented good Sir Rev. all ſhall be to your wiſh, I have prepar'd a courſe banquet for you Sir Rev.

sp.speaker: Sir Rev.
sp.p: She ſcorn a my love.

sp.speaker: Splend.
sp.l: This fool it ſeems is noted to be rich,
What's that to me? In dignity a Knight,
A Knight Sir Reverence, then he is of France,
The onely man of faſhion (from whoſe Countrey
All things are acceptable, no diſeaſe excepted)
Let him go ſeek a choiſe in his own Nation,
French feats grow ſtale, I'le have ſome newer faſhion;
I'le learn to love for worth, not one whoſe flaſhes
Blaze much, and are at one time flame and aſhes,
Give me a man whoſe love is built upon
Eternal vertue and perfection,
Who loves for mental worth, not outward ſhow,
And ſuch a one is my Mercurio.

div.head: Actus ſecundus, Scaena prima.

sp.speaker: Trimw.
sp.p: Art ſure thou ſawſt them go this way?

sp.speaker: Drow.
sp.p: Sure, yes ſure enough, I'm ſure they croſs'd this field, went o're that ſtile, and I am much deceived if I did not ſee Pimpwel peep out of yonder Tavern window.

sp.speaker: Trimw.
sp.l: That's the Kings-head I know't,
Oh for ſome queint diſguiſe,
My jealouſie hath yet no occular proof,
Theſe two years have I wandred in this maze,
And ſtill been blinded by her ſublil ſleights?
That Rivers is the man I moſt ſuſpect,
And yet I dare not think he wrongs my bed,
The very thought bred in a jealous breaſt,
Is proof enough, and then were he defenc'd
With Devils I would end him;
Oh! we vain men covet moſt to ſee
What we would not, my eyes can take no reſt;
How many Moonſhine nights and Summer evenings,
In various ſhapes have I walkt out to find her,
But never could?

sp.speaker: Drow.
sp.p: Would I had never ſeen the face of Mr. Flylove.

sp.speaker: Trim.
sp.l: Thou haſt even got, thy belly full of miſchief too,
But prethe do not cry out i'th fields, though I'm
A Surgeon, I ſhall make but a mad midwife,
Thou hadſt better repare to the City, and quietly,
For a month hire the next Cage is to be let, you
May buy a bed in Smith-feild, they come to Town,
In Cart-loads.

sp.speaker: Drow.
sp.l: No Sir, I know you'l lend me a room for one month,
I'le enquier for your houſe when I come to London,
How farr do you live from Cuckolds haven.

sp.speaker: Trim.
sp.p: A pox on you for a whore, you have wit enough to jeer though you had not to keep your Maiden-head.

sp.speaker: Drow.
sp.l: I pray Sir, is it not your black bird that ſings,
J cannot keep my wife at home, my wife at home.

sp.speaker: Trim.
sp.p: Out you greazy kitchen whore.

sp.speaker: Drow.
sp.p: Why thou foole, is not better to have ſuch a Greazy piece as I am, then to have a curious fine wife, and cannot come neer her.

sp.speaker: Trimwel.
sp.l: The whore ſayes true, how now who comes here,
Muſitians very good, I have a plot,
Come into my head, which by theſe fidlers,
Meanes I'le put in practiſe, hark you,
Honeſt Fidlers (Muſitians I ſhould call you)
I am a little Muſicall my ſelf, Gentlemen
Whither Croud you ſo faſt.

sp.speaker: Fidlers.
sp.p: Sir we are ſent for to play to Mr. Rivers at the Kings-head.

sp.speaker: Fid.
sp.p: The ſame Sir.

sp.speaker: Trim.
sp.p: Who playes the Citterne.

sp.speaker: Boy.
sp.p: That do I Sir.

sp.speaker: Trim.
sp.p: Very good, I have a plot that ſhall get you double the mony you expect.

sp.speaker: Fid.
sp.p: How is that I pray Sir.

sp.speaker: Trim.
sp.p: Why look, Franke Rivers is my only Companion, I would now ſteale upon him in the middle of's mirth diſguiſed like one of you, I have a falſe beard in my pocket, I'le carry the Baſe, counterfeit to be blind, and that boy ſhall lead me, and in the concluſion he ſhall pay you for the jeſt.

sp.speaker: Fid.
sp.p: With all our hearts Sir.

sp.speaker: Trim.
sp.p: Drowzy what will you do?

sp.speaker: Drow.
sp.p: Ile even home to London, but if you ſee Mr. Flyloeve tell him I'le ſerve him ſuch a trick as he ſaw in's life time, I'le warrant him.

sp.speaker: Trim.
sp.p: Farewell good Drowzy. Come Gentlemen let's about this buſineſs; Aha wife, yfaith I ſhall over-reach you now.

l.hi: I have been a Fidler theſe fifteen year,
And never was put in the Stocks before,
If an good fellow will give me ſome Beer,
I'le Fiddle and fuddle, and ner'e give o're.

div.stage: Enter Rivers, Wildblood, Flylove, Mrs. Bellaflora, and Mrs. Trimwell.

sp.speaker: Fly.
sp.p: Fair Lady you are welcome, I ſhoul ſalute you by your name if I knew it.

sp.speaker: Bella.
sp.p: My name is Mary Fair-chaſte.

sp.speaker: Fly.
sp.p: Fair and chaſt too, impoſſible; it is a Paradox to me.

sp.speaker: Bella.
sp.p: Is it ſuch wonder to be fair and chaſte Sir?

sp.speaker: Fly.
sp.p: No, no, 'tis no ſuch wonder, A fair Cabinet ſhould contain a fair Jewel; but ſince we have had poyſon in guilt bowls, killing Perfumes in rich Gloves, Hereſie in religious exact habit, and Treaſon in the well-ſeeming gravity of State, we put ſmall truſt in form; but what do I trouble you with theſe things, let's drink, ſing, dance, and be merry boyes;
sp.l: We come to be merry, &c. Sings.

div.p: Gentlemen, what ſhall we do for anoyſe of Vagrants, I have a dancing deſire to exerciſe my heels.

sp.speaker: Wild.
sp.p: I have ſent for Muſick, but we want a woman.

sp.speaker: Fly.
sp.p: Its impoſſible; Drawer.

sp.speaker: Draw.
sp.p: Did you call Sir?

sp.speaker: Fly.
sp.p: Intreat your Miſtris hither.

sp.speaker: Draw.
sp.p: I ſhal Sir, ſhe prevents my ſervice, ſhe's here already.

sp.speaker: Fly.
sp.p: How doth my Madona? my Belladoſſa? my Ent. Mrs. Sommer ſinner, the Connteſſe of Hogſdowne.

sp.speaker: Mrs.
sp.p: You give me many ſtiles Mr. Flylove.

sp.speaker: Fly.
sp.p: I have come over as many more ſtiles to behold thee my Queen of the Kings-head. Hark you; what rate holds womens fleſh? in breif haſt thou ever a peice of Impenitence, that will be ſociable, and will deſire, only her pleaſure for her paines, if ſhe can dance well, wee'l bear with any imperfection elſe; thou ſhalt not loſe all; wee'l ſeem to want the knowledg of thy over-reckoning, and pay thee. You know we are noe Cittizens, that (to eaſe our bodies and preſerve our pockets) keep a due Accompt of every quart and paper, by unbuttoning our doublets; or doubt our own memories by calling many reckonings at one ſitting.

sp.speaker: Mrs.
sp.p: You are very merry Mr. Flylove, but as I am a vertuous ſinner, you could never have choſe a time to have found me ſo unprovided in a whole ſummer, there is but one woman in the houſe, and ſhe is with a French man, yet I believe his greateſt buſineſs is over, if you will allow of his company you may have hers, nor will he be any interruption to you, for call what you will he'l pay freely, and be as merry as you will give him leave.

sp.speaker: Fly.
sp.p: Have they paid all?

sp.speaker: Mrs.
sp.p: They are now calling.

sp.speaker: Fly.
sp.p: Prethe entice them in.

sp.speaker: Mrs.
sp.p: No twill become you better, he may conceive I have ſome end of mine own in't; your way of invitation will intice him, the ſociety of an Engliſh Gentleman, is his only ambition.

sp.speaker: Fly.
sp.p: Very well; I'le invite him.

sp.speaker: Rivers.
sp.p: Whither go you Stephen?

sp.speaker: Bella.
sp.p: Sir I'le take my leave of you.

sp.speaker: Fly.
sp.p: By no means Lady, I'le return preſently, aſide. Jack Wildblood prethee entertain this Lady in my abſence, ſhe's modeſt, & thou art civil; but if you make your ſeeming civility a bawd to abuſe me, look to your ſelf.

sp.speaker: Wild.
sp.p: Well, well, pray follow your humor; Lady you are not merry.

sp.speaker: Bella.
sp.p: Is the Gentleman your friend gone?

sp.speaker: Wild.
sp.p: Some private occaſion, he'l be here ſuddenly.

sp.speaker: Bella.
sp.p: I cannot ſtay Sir.

sp.speaker: Pimp.
sp.p: Mr. Rivers; what is Mr. Flylove gone?

sp.speaker: Wild.
sp.p: where's the Muſick?

sp.speaker: Pimp.
sp.p: I have been as far as Redcroſſe-ſtreet for them, they were playing to a company of Cittizens at the Queens-head, but they told me they would make all the neceſſary expedition they could poſſible, and attend you in Hogsdon here at the Kings-head.

sp.speaker: Rivers.
sp.p: Nay, I'le ſay that for thee, thou art the happieſt Purveyor for Wine, Wenches and Muſick, that ever was aſſiſtant to the increaſe of ſinners.

sp.speaker: Pimpw.
sp.p: Who ſhould I meet withall coming from thence, through the Fortune-Playhouſe yard, but old Jones the Cobl.

sp.speaker: Wild.
sp.p: Thou ſhouldſt have brought him hither.

sp.speaker: Pimp.
sp.p: I thought you would have Wiſh'd ſo, and I have brought him.

sp.speaker: Rivers.
sp.p: A Cobler; what is he?

sp.speaker: Wild.
sp.p: What is he? why the rareſt humoriſt of a Cobler, that ever was tranſlated into merry company, his wit is jeering, tart in all ſuch jeaſts, nor will he ſpare the proudeſt he in pluſh. And ſpeaking in a moſt compoſed ſtrain, with countnance grave, no man can take exceptions, but may ſuppoſe it ignorance, not wit; You cannot chuſe but know him, that is he that owed fourty ſhillings to an Allderman, to pay 12. pence by the week, when he did exact Coblers law, and made his worſhipful creditor give him two pots at every payment.

sp.speaker: Riv.
sp.p: Yes, yes, I have heard of him.

sp.speaker: Pimp.
sp.p: Then now you ſhall ſee him, here comes the man in Perſon; welcome Mr. Jones.

sp.speaker: Jones.
sp.p: Thank you good Mr. Allexander, I'le make bold to ſalute theſe worthy Gentlemen, noble Mr. Wildblood, I take it.

sp.speaker: Wild.
sp.p: The very ſame Mr. Jones, and how did Mr. Alexander, and you meet.

sp.speaker: Jones.
sp.p:
Honeſt Mr. Pimpwell (here) was walking I believe
about his accaſions, I ſaw 2. or 3. Gentlemen with him, and introth becauſe I was in my workydaie Clothes, I was aſhamed to ſpeak with him, but I thank him good Gentleman, he call'd me to him, and told me I ſhould ſee ſome worthy Gentlemen of my acquaintance.

sp.speaker: Wild.
sp.p: Here Mr. Jones, I'le drink to you and to your wife, do you remember ſince you put her i'th cage?

sp.speaker: Jones.
sp.p: I pray Sir how long is't ſince we • ere merry at the Sargeons head in Iſlington, where we drank Sack ſo long till all our mony was gone, but introth I think I brought but a groat with me; we came off from the reckoning though prety handſomly, but good Gentleman you were forc'd to leave your ſilver Seal behinde, but I think you redeemed it again in a little while.

sp.speaker: Rivers.
sp.p: Ha, ha, ha, there he hath met you Jack.
sp.stage: Enter Flylove, Sir Reverence, Lamard, and Mrs. Light.

sp.speaker: Fly.
sp.p: Gentlemen I preſume to invite this worthy Gentleman and his Lady, I pray be courteous to them.

sp.speaker: Wild.
sp.p: Noble Sir, a friend of yours can never come unwelcome where we are; my ſervice Sir attends you.

sp.speaker: Sir Re.
sp.p: Monſieur your tres nmble umble vaſſale.

sp.speaker: Rivers.
sp.p: Sir according to our downright Engliſh Complement you are welcome.

sp.speaker: Sir R.
sp.p: Awee Monſieur, begar me tanke you heartely dere be Engliſh Complement for you agen, vat velow's dat?

sp.speaker: Wild.
sp.p: A very honeſt man Sir, and Beadle of the pariſh.

sp.speaker: Sir R.
sp.p: A beadle, begar he be no forboon company, my Madam can no endure a beadle.

sp.speaker: Jones.
sp.p: Alack good Gentlewoman; no Sir, I am no beadle I can aſſure you, though the Gentleman pleaſes to jeaſt.

sp.speaker: Sir R.
sp.p: Begar you look as like a rogua as a beadle.

sp.speaker: Jones.
sp.p: Alack, I believe Monſieur you have heard the ill newes lately come forth you are ſo angry of the ſudden.

sp.speaker: Sir R.
sp.p: Begar me have hear no ill news.

sp.speaker: Jones.
sp.p: then I'le tell you Sir, the ſad report goes that moſt of the Engliſh Gentlemen in France muſt return to England agen, I am ſorry for't.

sp.speaker: Sir R.
sp.p: Begar vas nothing but lies; how how vat is here, Fiddles? Madam ſall we dance?

stage.hi: Enter Muſitians, amongſt them, Trimwel diſguiſed like an old blind Fidler, and led in by a boy.

sp.speaker: Wild.
sp.p: Well done, you are honeſt Raſcalls, every man take his ſtool, ſtrike up couragiouſly, and be ſure have a ſpeciall care he that plays oth' baſe Violin ſleep not, we are no colls you know, you muſt not flam us.

sp.speaker: Riv.
sp.p: Come Gentlemen ſhall we try our footing, here am I.

sp.speaker: Fly.
sp.p: And here am I.

sp.speaker: Wild.
sp.p: And if this Gentleman pleaſe, here I'le be.

sp.speaker: Sir Rev.
sp.p: Vould all mine heart Monſieur.

sp.speaker: Bella.
sp.p: I cannot dance believe me Sir.

sp.speaker: Fly.
sp.p: Nor I, we'l onely practiſe.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Light.
sp.p: Excuſe me Sir, indeed I cannot dance.

sp.speaker: Wild.
sp.p: Excuſe me Sir, indeed I cannot dance? You ſhall not dance excuſe me then, that Country trip is old, we'l have ſome novelty.

sp.speaker: Riv.
sp.p: Are you perfect in the tune I gave you laſt to practiſe.

sp.speaker: Fidlers.
sp.p: Very perfect Sir.

sp.speaker: Rivers.
sp.p: Let me hear it.
sp.stage: They play the tune once over.

They dance the tune once over, then enter into a figure with, the beginning of the firſt ſtrain, Pimpwel and the Mrs. betwixt every change two perſons drink till it comes round, and Pimpw. diſcovers trimw. in the Dance, and at the end of ſeveral Changes he declares his diſcovery.

sp.speaker: Pimpw.
sp.p: Mrs. Trimwel do you obſerve that old fellow that plays oth' Baſe.
sp.stage: firſt Change. Wildb. and his Miſtris drink.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Trimw.
sp.p: Well, what of that?

sp.speaker: Pimpw.
sp.p: By my life 'tis your Husband.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Trim.
sp.p: My Husband?

sp.speaker: Pimpw.
sp.p: Take no notice.

sp.speaker: Wild.
sp.p: Come t'other Change.
sp.stage: They dance, at the end of the next Change Flyl. and his Mrs. drink.

sp.speaker: Fly.
sp.p: Lady my ſervice to you.

sp.speaker: Bella.
sp.p: Pray let it be your love Sir, Twill make the Health much ſweeter.

sp.speaker: Rivers.
sp.p: Thou mak'ſt me wonder.
sp.stage: At the end of the next Change Mrs. Trim. and Rives drink.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Trim.
sp.p: As I live 'tis true.

sp.speaker: Rivers.
sp.p: What? he that plays the Baſe?

sp.speaker: Fly.
sp.p: Come to the next.

sp.speaker: Trim.
sp.p: Here is ſtrange humours in this This laſt Change Pimpw. and the Miſtris drink. Dance, how they drink and whiſper, as if they had capering minds as well as bodies; Hey! I how my wife trips it, when ſhe comes home ſhe was with one Aunt or other; She's no Tavern-dancing company, no, no; Oh my bleſt diſguiſe.

sp.speaker: Pimw.
sp.p: Oh your Bulls-head, we'l take a courſe to order you, you blind puppy, becauſe you wink you think no body can ſee you; Come the tother Change, and conclude.

sp.speaker: Sir Rev.
sp.p: Begar vas moſe brave, my They dance the laſt Change of all. Lady dance al lemode like our Frenſh Madam.

sp.speaker: Jones.
sp.p: Introth Mr. Flylove you dance very well, but that you ſtraddle ſo much, but if you take it in time that may be altered; Oh Mr. Flylove you have a little gone awry, but mum for that.

sp.speaker: Fly.
sp.p: Well ſaid Mr. Jones, do you remember one night when you caſt Anchor ith' kennel, and call'd to the Goldfinder for a Coach, who mounted you in his Chariot, and drew you to the River Acharon at the back-ſide of Iſlington.

sp.speaker: Jones.
sp.p: Oh! Mr. Flylove you are an ingenious Gentleman, I have heard high commendations of you by a Neighbours daughter a friend of mine.

sp.speaker: Fly.
sp.p: Prethee who's that?

sp.speaker: Jones.
sp.p: 'Tis a very good natur'd Laſs, if ſhe knew you were here, ſhe would have a quart of Wine at your ſervice.

sp.speaker: Fly.
sp.p: Do I know her?

sp.speaker: Jones.
sp.p: Do you know her? Do I know Jone my wife? Do not you know Alice Drowzy?

sp.speaker: Fly.
sp.p: Pox on you hold your tongue, this dirty whore hants me in a thouſand ſhapes, I muſt throw her out of my memory. Come Gentlemen ſhall we have another Dance?

sp.speaker: Rivers.
sp.p: Come Gentlemen t'other Dance.

sp.speaker: Sir Rev.
sp.p: I come, me like de Dance better den Song.
sp.stage:
They all dance to a ſprightly Ayr, but in the fourth
Change they all dance off from the Stage into the Tyringhouſe, where they remain till the tune it plaid once over; then they dance all in again, and come to their ſeverall Figures, and continue dancing the tune once more over; then they dance in and out again as before; At the laſt they Dance quite away from the houſe, leaving the Fidlers to play to the Monſieur, Mr. Jones, and themſelvs; having played an unreaſonable while, they deſiſt, and the Monſieur ſpeaks.

sp.speaker: Sir Rev.
sp.p: Hold, hold good Monſieur Minikin, for begar dey have dance avay wid my Ladce; Rogue, Drawer. Ent. Draw.

sp.speaker: Draw.
sp.p: Anon, anon Sir.

sp.speaker: Sir Rev.
sp.p: Fere be de Zhentlemen and de Ladce.

sp.speaker: Draw.
sp.p: They have taken Coach Sir, and are at London by this time.

sp.speaker: Fidlers.
sp.p: How? how?

sp.speaker: Sir Rev.
sp.p: Begar me never ſaw ſuſh a frisk in my life; Vas dis de skip de Angleteire?

sp.speaker: Drawer.
sp.p: I was bid to deliver this Note to him that plays on the Baſe?

sp.speaker: Trim.
sp.p: To me? give me't.

sp.speaker: Draw.
sp.p: Yes, they ſay your ill fidling made them all dance quite away, they would have ſtaid longer elſe.

sp.speaker: Trim.
sp.p: The Devils have unridled me; what's here?

l.hi: The Woodcock when his head is hid,
Fool when thou comeſt next to find us,
Bring ſome better trick to blind us;
Pay the reckning, or you'l finde,

sp.speaker: Jones.
sp.p: What have you there Sir, a Bill of Exchange?

sp.speaker: Trim.
sp.p: Pox on your Cobling jeaſts, Trimwell pulls off his grey beard. you quibling Coxcombe I am undone for ever.

sp.speaker: Sir Rev.
sp.p: Begar de Fidler be mad, he tear his hair off.

sp.speaker: Jones.
sp.p: Who's this? My old acquaintance Mr. Trimwel.

sp.speaker: Trimw.
sp.p: Hang up your old acquaintance, do not trouble me, who would have thought that through this diſguiſe their careleſs eyes ſhould thus diſcover me, but I'le follow them as cloſe as Death doth ſin.

sp.speaker: Draw.
sp.p: Sir you muſt pay the Reckoning firſt.

sp.speaker: Trim.
sp.p: Shall I.

sp.speaker: Draw.
sp.p: Before you part, it is your device hath made us loſe the beſt Gueſts that come to our houſe.

sp.speaker: Trim.
sp.p: How much is it?

sp.speaker: Draw.
sp.p: One pound thirteen and nine pence.

sp.speaker: Trim.
sp.p: Here's the French Knight, one of their company that call'd it in, let him diſcharge it.

sp.speaker: Sir Rev.
sp.p: Diſharge it, begar my Lady The Frenchman feels in's pockets. have left me noting to diſharge, ſhe got all my mony and my Waſh.

sp.speaker: Jones.
sp.p: Gentlemen, I'le go pay my part at the bar.

sp.speaker: Draw.
sp.p: Your part, what's that?

sp.speaker: Jones.
sp.p: A three-pence, a good three-pence, a Spaniſh 3. d. and ſo farewell to you both good Gent.

sp.speaker: Trim.
sp.p: Well, there's your mony Drawer, I muſt confeſs I drank for't.

sp.speaker: Fidlers.
sp.p: Who ſhall pay us Sir?

sp.speaker: Trim.
sp.p: The Devil pay't, ſhall I be made a But for every knave to ſhoot at.

sp.speaker: Fidlers.
sp.p: Sir, you are the cauſe that we have not only loſt this mony, but our credit with the Gentlemen, if we had known you had been a Trapan, you ſhould ne'r have been admitted into our company; you had other pretences.

sp.speaker: Trim.
sp.p: Well, ſince 'twas my plot, I am like to pay for't, there's a French crown among you, pray get you from me. Sir, you are a ſtranger, and therefore I Exeunt Fidlers. have nothing more to ſay to you, but to deſire your abſence.

sp.speaker: Sir Rev.
sp.p: Mee bee glad mee come off ſo, farewel Monſieur Bo-peep.

sp.speaker: Trim.
sp.l: The juſt cauſe of my fears I now perceive,
As evident as day-light; in this Dance
There is compos'd all that her wanton heart
Can give, or he can covet, I muſt now
Turn all my love to loathing; Sweet Revenge
I am thy faithful Votary, I will ſtill
Purſue their foot-ſteps, and with wary eyes,
Watch their Adulterous Conſpiracies:
Now I have thought upon't, if they defend
Their perſons from this plot I now intend,
I will disband my reaſon, and reſign
My Intellectuals, or what elſe is mine:
Look to it Gallants, the next time you view me,
I'le make you curſe the time that e're you knew me.

sp.speaker: Mercu.
sp.l: Time and our fitter opportunity,
The pleaſant entertainment of our love
Hath almoſt waſted; 'tis an hour neer night,
And we can tread no farther then to'th place
Thy Father hath expell'd me, we muſt part,
But urg'd to't with much more unwillingneſs,
Then heat from life, when ſouls and bodies ſeperate.

sp.speaker: Splend.
sp.l: Thou ſhalt not leave me yet, I'le plant my love
Above my fear, it is a nobler paſſion,
Nor ſhall my fathers frown have more command
On my affection, then thy brow, made ſmooth
By thy own love, credit me gentle youth,
Thou haſt next rule in this weak manſion
To him that built it.
sp.stage: Ent. Nice. Sir Rev. Trimwel and two Serjeants.

sp.speaker: Nice.
sp.p: That's he.

sp.speaker: 1. Ser.
sp.p: We know him Sir.

sp.speaker: Nice.
sp.p: Perform your task then.

sp.speaker: 2. Ser.
sp.p: I'le warrant you.

sp.speaker: Sir Rev.
sp.p: Begar me have waſh him hither, now me ſall be revenge.

sp.speaker: Nice.
sp.p: Stay not for bayl, I'le double your reward.

sp.speaker: 1. Ser.
sp.p: You are a kind Gentleman: Sir we arreſt you by the name of Mercurio.

sp.speaker: Merc.
sp.p: Arreſt me Sir, who hath employ'd you for this Action? At whoſe ſuit is't?

sp.speaker: 2. Ser.
sp.p: At the Suit of Mr. Nice, a very honeſt Gentleman I can aſſure you.

sp.speaker: Merc.
sp.p: You gueſs that by his bounty for your baſeneſs: What is the ſum?

sp.speaker: 1. Ser.
sp.p: Twenty pounds upon bond, if you have ſpeciall Bayl, produce it preſently, we cannot ſtay.

sp.speaker: Merc.
sp.p: Why is your time ſo precious that is ſpent to ruine man-kind, be not pray ſo haſty, where is the Gentleman?

sp.speaker: 2. Ser.
sp.p: He is not far Sir.

sp.speaker: Nice.
sp.p: What is your wil with me.

sp.speaker: Merc.
sp.p: Longer time for payment of your debt.

sp.speaker: Nice.
sp.p: I may forbear no longer, Sir you know the mony hath been due theſe 14. weeks, it is in vain to think you can urge me to an agreement, but my preſent ſum.

sp.speaker: Splend.
sp.p: But not, I intreat that mercy Sir.

sp.speaker: Nice.
sp.p: Fond Girl ask mercy for your diſodedience, I have appear'd too temperate with you, and ſhown too much indulgence; 'tis your cauſe that makes him ſuffer.

sp.speaker: Splend.
sp.l: And 'tis his abuſe
Will make me periſh; Oh remember Sir
You had a wife, my Mother, whoſe dear duſt
With low and humble reverence I kiſs:
Had you been ſeiz'd between two Tygers thus,
Would't not have mov'd her, made her plyant knees
Grow toth' dull earth, till the deaf Creditor,
(By importunacy more then compunction)
Had ſeal'd a truce 'twixt him and's undone Debtor.

sp.speaker: Nice.
sp.l: Your ſuperſtitious knees in vain are bent
For this bad cauſe, Laws Moral and Divine,
Have ſtill provided that each man ſhall claim
What is his right, I but exact mine own.

sp.speaker: Splend.
sp.l: What can you call your own, that you may ſpare,
Whilſt ſtill the cryes of widdows, injur'd Orphans
Beat at the ears of pitty; had this man
(Trapt in the ſnares of Canibals) his own
The fair inheritance his birthright claims,
(Heaven pardon them that have it) I believe
You need not rack his body for your owne.

sp.speaker: Nice.
sp.p: Your zeal makes you forget your ſelf.

sp.speaker: Splend.
sp.l: My ſorrow is too bold indeed, to ſee
Such pregnant hopes thus blaſted in the bloom
Of teeming growth, nipt in the ſpringing bud
Of ſpreading youth; to ſee mans ſpan contracted,
Sent to the grave e're yet he can conceive
The end of his Creation, 'cauſe his Cheſts
Want coyn, not to ſupply, but cram anothers:
Joves great impreſſion ſuffers this decay,

For want of Caeſar •
Image ſtampt in Clay.

sp.speaker: Nice.
sp.p: I'le hear no more.

sp.speaker: Splend.
sp.l: A little pray Sir,
He that's ſo indigent to want the means
Of rendring your right, whilſt he enjoys
His fair and open freedom; Can you believe,
That being cloſe pent up with Iron barrs,
Stone walls and Jaylors hearts,
Where every cowardly Creditor treads down,
The o'rethrown Debtor with a doubled ſum,
That ſtands bayl-proof; is that a time to ſatisfie,
Unleſs he had the Elixor to convert
The Iron grates to Gold, or (which is beſt)
To nothing.

sp.speaker: Nice.
sp.p: Officers what ſtay you for?

sp.speaker: 1. Ser.
sp.p: Come will you go Sir.

sp.speaker: Splend.
sp.l: How diligent in cruelty you are:
Have you the heart to think this good old man
(That knows the ſcales unto Eternity
Are pitty, mercy, love (the beſt Religion)
Fear of oppreſſion) will commit his youth
To your ungentle uſage?

sp.speaker: 2. Ser.
sp.p: Pray be not mov'd with us, your father may releaſe him.

sp.speaker: Splend.
sp.l: Look Sir, the Officers grow merciful,
And ſeem to bear no part in his undoing;
Shall men that ſtudy nought but cruelty,
Out-doe you in an act of gentleneſs?

sp.speaker: Nice.
sp.p: Officers, I'le leave him to your charge, take Bayle at your peril.

sp.speaker: Splend.
sp.p: Sir Reverence, will you be bayl for him, you are good for nothing elſe.

sp.speaker: Sir Rev.
sp.p: Begar me be no bayl.

sp.speaker: Splend.
sp.p: There's a day for thee when no bayl ſhalbe taken; Shall I ſpeak one word with your Priſoner?

sp.speaker: 1. Ser.
sp.p: Two if you pleaſe.

sp.speaker: Trim.
sp.p: Hark you Mr. Tripes, I ſhal find you at the Compter gate.

sp.speaker: 2. Ser.
sp.p: Without fail.

sp.speaker: Trim.
sp.p: I have another miſchievous imployment for you.

sp.speaker: 1. Ser.
sp.p: We ſhall endeavour to perform it Sir.

sp.speaker: Trim.
sp.p: Oh Sir, I know you to be deſerving men; there's money, enter an Action againſt Stephen Flylove at the ſuit of Alice Drowzy in an Action of aſſault and battery committed upon the belly of the ſaid Alice laſt May, the Planets being Venus and Mars Rampant, and the Sign Virgo.

sp.speaker: 2. Ser.
sp.p: I apprehend you Sir.

sp.speaker: Trim.
sp.p: Apprehend me Sir, for what? you are deceived, you muſt apprehend Mr. Flylove.

sp.speaker: 2. Ser.
sp.p: I underſtand you Sir.

sp.speaker: Trim.
sp.p: Farewel my underſtanding Serjeant,

sp.speaker: Merc.
sp.p: Come we muſt part.

sp.speaker: Splend.
sp.p: I'l come and viſit thee.

sp.speaker: Merc.
sp.p: Thy ſight in priſon is my liberty.

sp.speaker: Fly.
sp.p: Can you conceit why I have ſingled you thus from the company.

sp.speaker: Bella.
sp.p: No, pray inſtruct me Sir.

sp.speaker: Fly.
sp.p: The inſtructions are too eaſie to be good, ſince you appear ſo innocently modeſt; I'le be your amorous Schoolmaſter for once.

sp.speaker: Bella.
sp.p: You'l teach me no ill Doctrine.

sp.speaker: Fly.
sp.p: No, no, prethee obſerve me, be but capable, and I'le warrant thee an apt Scholler.

sp.speaker: Bella.
sp.p: Well-Sir, ſo far as I perceive it's good, I'le learn.

sp.speaker: Fly.
sp.p: I'le ſhew you the Lovers Alphabet, be obſervant then, and be not ſqueamiſh, but do as I direct you; When a Gentleman and's Lady do meet, A. the firſt letter is A ſalutation.

sp.speaker: Bella.
sp.p: The word begins with S.

sp.speaker: Fly.
sp.p: No matter for the word, give me the ſence, B. the next letter, lend me your fair hand.

sp.speaker: Bella.
sp.p: Very good Sir.

sp.speaker: Fly.
sp.p: 'Tis in a very good hand indeed; nay I'le ſhew you more tricks by and by, it is ſo very fair that I muſt kiſs it, there's a letter gone that ſtands for C.I confeſs C. may ſtand for another buſineſs, and ſitter for the letter, but a kiſs ſhall ſerve at this time.

sp.speaker: Bella.
sp.p: On I pray Sir.

sp.speaker: Fly.
sp.p: Nay, I ſhall come on faſt enough, I warrant you. D. ſhall joyn both our hands, now do we look as if we were wreſtling, which of us both ſhould give the firſt kiſs.

sp.speaker: Bella.
sp.p: You make your own conſtruction Sir.

sp.speaker: Fly.
sp.p: I, I, no matter, it's nere the worſe for that.

sp.speaker: Bella.
sp.p: Proceed Sir.

sp.speaker: Fly.
sp.p: Stay, ſtay, let's pauſe a little, you'l forget it agen elſe, E. is embrace me, there I have hit you to a letter.

sp.speaker: Bella.
sp.p: You come neer me now Sir.

sp.speaker: Fly.
sp.p: I ſhall come neerer yet, for F. I'le ſtroak your cheek.

sp.speaker: Bella.
sp.p: F. ſtands for flattery.

sp.speaker: Fly.
sp.p: Not at this time fair one, if you will tye me punctually to a better F. ſtands for Faith or Friendſhip.

sp.speaker: Bella.
sp.p: That is the trueſt uſe on't.

sp.speaker: Fly.
sp.p: Well, it ſhall go ſo then. G. is a Gift.

sp.speaker: Bella.
sp.p: I'le wear it.

sp.speaker: Fly.
sp.p: Let me ſee you.

sp.speaker: Bella.
sp.p: Firſt make an end.

sp.speaker: Fly.
sp.p: H. ſtands for Hug me t' you.

sp.speaker: Bella.
sp.p: I have heard of a Wine call'd by that name Sir.

sp.speaker: Fly.
sp.p: Were it Nectar it could not be ſweeter then this.

sp.speaker: Bella.
sp.p: It ſeems your favour and my embrace do want no acceptation.

sp.speaker: Fly.
sp.p: I. ſtands for you, and K. ſtanding for kiſs, is I kiſs you. By the breath of Venus y'have a pleaſant lip.

sp.speaker: Bella.
sp.p: I'm glad it pleaſeth you; to the next letter.

sp.speaker: Fly.
sp.p: L. is another kiſs, it ſtands for Love.

sp.speaker: Bella.
sp.p: L. may be luſt, but it ſhould be Love.

sp.speaker: Fly.
sp.p: I, I, it may ſtand for both by fits. M. ſtands for Mary.

sp.speaker: Bella.
sp.p: So it may for Marry.

sp.speaker: Fly.
sp.p: Remember R. ſtands for repent, but I am far enough off from that. N, is the next letter, N. ſtands for ne're be good, you ſhall learn O. Q. P. V. in private, that is the full prick or concluſion of the Lovers Alphabet.

sp.speaker: Bella.
sp.l: Take heed, be not too haſty.
Some that would ſeem more nice then vertuous.
Who uſe a bluſh, or modeſt baſhfulneſs,
To vail their knowledge of ill propoſitions,
(Such as I'm ſure pou make, though y'have a trick
To ſmooth it o're with your methodick wantonneſs)
Would be aſham'd to tell you your ill meaning,
But I will not.
L. in your Alphabet doth ſtand for luſt,
And be not fool'd with ſuch a vanity,
To think becauſe you are a handſome man,
Or I ſo eaſie won to your ſociety,
That I will do an act may hold proportion
With any baſeneſs; if you can love truly,
Without a glance to any vild reſpect,
Reveal it, I was never ſo ill bred
To give diſcourteous anſwers.

sp.speaker: Fly.
sp.l: Love, and love truly, are not you married?

sp.speaker: Bella.
sp.l: I am not now Sir.

sp.speaker: Fly.
sp.l: A widdow and ſo cautious, I'le try another ways;
Have I taken up an Angle inſtead of a Bona Roba?
Yes I can love thee, and can love thee truly, and heartily,
He ſwear ſo if thou'lt have me.

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: Let me but hear you Sir, I'le ſwear as much.

sp.speaker: Fly.
sp.p: Wilt thou, faith ſtay a little.

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: What do you pauſe on't Sir?

sp.speaker: Fly.
sp.p: No, no, I'm ready enough to ſwear, I am loath to caſt away too big an oath, and I'm afraid a ſmal one wil not ſuffice her.

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: Come I'le propoſe the Oath.

sp.speaker: Fly.
sp.p: With all my heart.

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: By tho • e diviner powers that govern Contracts, Swear to be true to me.

sp.speaker: Fly.
sp.p: By all thoſe ſacred powers I kiſs the book, & ever wil obſerve it, come ſhal we walk a ſide now: Kiſſes her. Whoſe here?

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: I am glad you are prevented; How vainly men in their raſh heat will ſwear to what they ne'r intend.
sp.stage: Enter Riv. Wild. and Mrs. Trimwel.

sp.speaker: Wild.
sp.p: How now Stephen, what do you flye from your Colours?

sp.speaker: Fly.
sp.p: No Sir, I flye to my Colours, red and white, I'm a right Engliſh-man▪

sp.speaker: Riv.
sp.p: Where's Pimpwel gone?

sp.speaker: Fly.
sp.p: I ſent him for more Money.

sp.speaker: Wild.
sp.p: But that Heaven ordained al things for a good end, a man might ſwear that Pimpwel was created for a Pimp: how cunningly he found her husband out, & how ſuddenly the rogue contriv'd that quick eſcape; I will have him put in the Almanack next to the Gunpowder-Treaſon.

sp.speaker: Rivers.
sp.p: Or Gowries Conſpiracy; In what a ſtammering caſe now is my French-man; and now I think upon him, I have ſeen a face as right like that in Parris.

sp.speaker: Wild.
sp.p: Faith ſo have I.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Trim.
sp.p: Were you e'r in France Mr. Rivers?

sp.speaker: River.
sp.p: Yes Sweetheart.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Trim.
sp.p: I have had a brother there theſe 14. years, and have not heard-from him.

sp.speaker: Riv.
sp.p: What part of France?

sp.speaker: Wild.
sp.p: What was his name?

sp.speaker: Wild.
sp.p: I never heard of him.

sp.speaker: Fly.
sp.p: Haſt thou brought the mony.

sp.speaker: Pimp.
sp.p: Ther's. 5. l.

sp.speaker: Fly.
sp.p: Go and beſpeak ſupper at the John of Jeruſalem.

sp.speaker: Pim.
sp.p: I fear it's too late.

sp.speaker: Fly.
sp.p: What's a clock?

sp.speaker: Pim.
sp.p: Paſt 9.

sp.speaker: Fly.
sp.p: No matter; Lady you ſhall not leave me.

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: Indeed I cannot ſtay, to morrow where you pleaſe I'le keep an hour with you.

sp.speaker: Fly.
sp.p: we'l drink a pint & talk on't

sp.speaker: Pimpw.
sp.p: I'le tell you news, The French Knight's arreſted at the ſuit of Mr. Bonaventure an Engliſh Merchant for 6000. pound, is gone to priſon, no bayl will be taken.

sp.speaker: Fly.
sp.p: I'm ſorry for't; go, prethee make haſte.

sp.speaker: Pimpw.
sp.p: I am gone.

sp.speaker: Port.
sp.p: Gentlemen, my buſineſs is to one Mr. Elylove, Can you direct me to him?

sp.speaker: Fly.
sp.p: What is your buſineſs Porter?

sp.speaker: Port.
sp.p: I pray read that Letter Sir, I received it from a young Gentleman.

sp.speaker: Fly.
sp.p: Gentleman! I hope it is no news from Drowzy. To my friend Stephen Flylove; I'le try what your inſide ſayes; Ha, come with all ſpeed, Gentlemen I have ſad news for you, Mercurio is arreſted.

sp.speaker: Wild.
sp.p: Arreſted!

sp.speaker: Riv.
sp.p: What devil did the deed?

sp.speaker: Fly.
sp.p: Nice the rich Merchant, 'tis but 20. l.

sp.speaker: Riv.
sp.p: But 20. l. alas poor Gentleman, he can as wel diſcharge 1000.

sp.speaker: Fly.
sp.p: He hath writ to ſpeak with me, he is not yet in priſon.

sp.speaker: Wild.
sp.p: Where is he?

sp.speaker: Fly.
sp.p: At the Harrow-Tavern in Little Woodſtreet.

sp.speaker: Wild.
sp.p: Come we'l all go, perhaps they'l take our Bayl.

sp.speaker: Riv.
sp.p: No hang them, theſe Citizens will take none but Free men; We'l make a tryal though.

sp.speaker: Wild.
sp.p: I would Pimywel were here agen, I am ſorry you appointed a Supper.

sp.speaker: Fly.
sp.p: No matter, we ſhall know ſome end on't ſuddenly.

sp.speaker: Riv.
sp.p: Let us defer no time, at the Harrow-Tavern ſay you.

sp.speaker: Bella.
sp.p: Sir I muſt take my leave of you at next turning.

sp.speaker: Fly.
sp.p: Well, meet me at the Jeruſalem-Tavern, but be ſure you fail not.

sp.speaker: Bella.
sp.p: Your injunction ſhall be obſerved?

sp.speaker: Fly.
sp.p: I'le leave a Glove at bar.

div.head: Act. 3. Scaen. 3.
div.stage: Enter Mr. Hemlock, Mrs. Hemlock, Trimwel, Mace & Trip • s.

sp.speaker: Trim.
sp.p: Mrs. Hemlock if you and your husband do not aſſiſt me in this plot of dexterious miſchief (ſiniſter I ſhould call it) I ſhal be diſgraced beyond remedy; I have now met with an opportunity ſo pleaſing, ſo fit, ſo apt to entertain my purpoſe, an hour where only Saturn is predominant, ſhall ſo jerk my light-heel'd Gallants, and the politick little Gypſie my wife, Flylove is the pin that muſt ſet all the other wheels a going, which pin this honeſt blade my old acquaintance Tripes ſhall turn, Mr. Mace I know your part is not the leaſt in thiſ revengeful conſpiracy, be ſure you uſe him roughly that it may cauſe a quarrel, and young Rivers will take fire at the leaſt ſpark.

sp.speaker: Tripes.
sp.p:
If ſcurvy uſage will make them quarrel they ſhal not want it, I hope Tripes is not to learn to uſe a man ſcurvily,
I'm ſure I have practiz'd theſe 20. years, and there's never a one that ever I arreſted yet can give me a good word; The Players brought me oth' Stage once I thank them in a Play call'd the Roaring Girle, or The Catchpole, he was a pretty fellow that acted me, but he came ſhort of the rogueries I have done.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Hem.
sp.p: You have ſent a Porter.

sp.speaker: Trim.
sp.p: I ſaw him deliver the Letter.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Hem.
sp.p: 'Tis very well, 'cauſe this is a large room, you ſhall retire into a leſs, I'le ſhew them up ſtayrs, and pretend that Mercurio and the Serjeants are gone into the City to ſee ſome friend of his for bayl, and will be here preſently, which to countenance you ſhall leave your pint pot half full of wine, your empty foul pipes and the candle, and when I ſhall give the watch-word you may enter.

sp.speaker: Trimwel.
sp.p: And now you talk of the watch-word, is the Watch ſet at Cripplegate?

sp.speaker: Mrs. Hem.
sp.p: And hath been this half hour.

sp.speaker: Trim.
sp.p: If there be but the leaſt diſturbance, let your boy be ready to call the Watch up; can he frame a lye hanſomly before the Juſtice next morning, I know the Watch will do their parts, only they have one fault, which is to charge every offender with one way of aſſault, that muſt be avoided.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Hem.
sp.p: I warrant you for the boy Ned.

sp.speaker: Boy.
sp.p: Anon, anon Sir, Did you call Mr.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Hem.
sp.p: Yes Sir.

sp.speaker: Trim.
sp.p: Is thy name Villanous?

sp.speaker: Boy.
sp.p: No Sir, 'tis a nick-name my Mr. hath given me.

sp.speaker: Trim.
sp.p: But thou muſt now deſerve it, can you if need be, abuſe. I mean accuſe a Gentleman before a Juſtice of peace, to do a courtefie for a friend of your Maſters?

sp.speaker: Boy.
sp.p: Of what degree muſt the fault be?

sp.speaker: Trim.
sp.p: Of what degree? a learned boy, oh my dainty pickpocket, he hath faults at's fingers ends, the devil hath given us ſuch equal gifts; let me hear your degrees my fine villain.

sp.speaker: Trim.
sp.p: Time runs away, let me hear ſom of them preſently.

sp.speaker: Boy.
sp.p: Why ſir, I can accuſe him for picking of your kocket calling you ſon of a whore Rogue, Knave, Cheat, ſtriking of you with a ſword, with a ſtaff, with a pot, a Candleſtick, or ſtab'd you with a Tobacco-pipe, or — are you married?

sp.speaker: Trim.
sp.p: Yes Sir.

sp.speaker: Boy.
sp.p: Then if you will Sir, I'le ſwear I ſaw him lye with your wife.

sp.speaker: Trim.
sp.p: No, no, hang you, I'le have thee ſwear to nothing that appears like truth, you ſhall find cauſe enough to ſwear I'le warrant you, and ſo we ſhall have all.

sp.speaker: Tripes.
sp.p: I ſhould know this boy, a pretty ingenious Lad; Doſt thou not know me, Jack?

sp.speaker: Boy.
sp.p: My name's Richard Philpot, I was born in Turnbal-ſtreet

sp.speaker: Tripes.
sp.p: 'Tis true, 'tis true, doſt not know me Dick Filpot?

sp.speaker: Boy.
sp.p: No truly Sir.

sp.speaker: Tripes.
sp.p: How doth thy father, is thy mother living ſtill?

sp.speaker: Boy.
sp.p: No Sir, ſhe's dead; did you know her Sir?

sp.speaker: Tripes.
sp.p: Did I know her, I a dozen years before I knew thee, why thou art now, let me ſee, 1641. thou art now ſome 14. years of age Dick.

sp.speaker: Boy.
sp.p: I am almoſt 15. Sir.

sp.speaker: Tripes.
sp.p: I think thou wantſt half a year on't.

sp.speaker: Boy.
sp.p: No Sir, I want but a quarter.

sp.speaker: Tripes.
sp.p: I, thereabouts, didſt never hear thy father ſpeak of me Dick.

sp.speaker: Boy.
sp.p: No indeed Sir.

sp.speaker: Tripes.
sp.p: I am thy Godfather.

sp.speaker: Boy.
sp.p: Are you Sir?

sp.speaker: Tripes.
sp.p: Am I quotha, who would have thought to have ſeen this boy here; do thy duty, I ſhal find ſomthing for thee.

sp.speaker: Boy.
sp.p: Pray Godfather give me your bleſſing.

sp.speaker: Tripes.
sp.p: Good boy, thou art no Browniſt, I ſee thou canſt kneel to thy Godfather for a gift, ſo can ſom of them too for thy hopes, but y faith boy I cannot part with mony at this time, thou ſhalt have my bleſſing.

sp.speaker: Omnes.
sp.p: Ha, ha, ha.

sp.speaker: Boy.
sp.p: A pox of your bleſſing, I thought how wel you were my Godfather; had it not been for the hopes of your mony I'le have ſeen you hang'd e'r I'le have beleeved you, I know where my Godfathers are, though I'de have ſatisfied your humor for your mony.

sp.speaker: Trim.
sp.p: Boy look to your charge, they are come.

sp.speaker: Boy.
sp.p: By and by, anon, anon Sir.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Hem.
sp.p: Go all of you into that room.

sp.speaker: Mr. Hem.
sp.p: The watch-words ſhall be, I wonder he ſtayes ſo long.

sp.speaker: Mr. Trim.
sp.p: I would not have you ſeen.

sp.speaker: Trim.
sp.p: No, I'le warrant you.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Hem.
sp.p: You are very welcom Gent.
sp.stage: Ent. Wild. Fly. Riv. & Mrs. Trim.

sp.speaker: Wild.
sp.p: Are you the Maſter of the houſe?

sp.speaker: Mr. Hem.
sp.p: Yes Sir, for want of a better.

sp.speaker: Wild.
sp.p: It may be ſo; what ſhall I call your name?

sp.speaker: Mr. Hem.
sp.p: My name is Hemlock Sir.

sp.speaker: Fly.
sp.p: Thou art half hang'd, thou haſt an ill name Hemlock and a Vintner, bleſs me from thy wine; did there not a couple of Serjeants bring in a Gentleman even now?

sp.speaker: Mr. H.
sp.p: Yes Sir, are you the Gentleman he ſent for?

sp.speaker: Fly.
sp.p: Where is he?

sp.speaker: Mr. H.
sp.p: He and the Serjeants are gone into Cheapſide to a friend of his that he hopes will bayl him, they'l be here preſently, this is his room.

sp.speaker: Fly.
sp.p: Why would not that friend come hither?

sp.speaker: Mrs. H.
sp.p: He was in bed Sir.

sp.speaker: Fly.
sp.p: A poor excuſe, that man will ſcarce be bayl, that will not have his bed to ſave his friend.

sp.speaker: Mr.
sp.p: I hope Sir you will do him ſome good, he's a pretty Gentleman, 'tis pitty he ſhould ſuffer.

sp.speaker: Fly.
sp.p: It is indeed, hath he paid the reckning.

sp.speaker: Mr.
sp.p: No Sir.

sp.speaker: Fly.
sp.p: How long hath he been gone?

sp.speaker: Mr.
sp.p: Half an hour Sir, I wonder he ſtays ſo long.

sp.speaker: Wild.
sp.p: How now, who are theſe?

sp.speaker: Tripes.
sp.p: Is your name Mr. Flylove?

sp.speaker: Fly.
sp.p: Yes Sir.

sp.speaker: Tripes.
sp.p: I arreſt you at the ſuit of Alice Drowzy.
sp.stage: Riv. draws, offers to run at the Serj. and the Mr. oth' houſe comming between, he is hurt ith' arm, then coms in the miſtris.

sp.speaker: Riv.
sp.p: Arreſt my friend?

sp.speaker: Wild.
sp.p: Then let me ſuffer too.

sp.speaker: Mr. H.
sp.p: Murder, murder, murder, go run and call the Watch, my husband's kill'd.

sp.speaker: Conſtable.
sp.p: Beat down their weapons, I charge you in the Kings name to keep his peace.

sp.speaker: Riv.
sp.p: The Kings peace we will keep.

sp.speaker: Conſt.
sp.p: Or we ſhall force you.

sp.speaker: Riv.
sp.p: Did nothing urge me to't but your force, I ſhould not fear to break it.

sp.speaker: Conſt.
sp.p: Sir you have kill'd the Maſter of the houſe.

sp.speaker: Riv.
sp.p: I'm very ſorry for't Sir.

sp.speaker: Conſt.
sp.p: That is no ſatisfaction.

sp.speaker: Riv.
sp.p: He is a man I meant no hurt to; Sir do you ſend for Chyrurgeon to night, I'le ſend you one to morrow, I gueſs the danger of the wound; Come Sir, where will you conduct us?

sp.speaker: Conſt.
sp.p: To the next priſon.

sp.speaker: Wild.
sp.p: Oh that's the Compter.

sp.speaker: Riv.
sp.p: Come then we'l altogether and make a merry night, no queſtion but we ſhall come off to morrow; I pray Mr. Conſtable will you come for us betimes.

sp.speaker: Conſt.
sp.p: You ſhall have all the favour I can do you, I am ſorry for this chance.

sp.speaker: Fly.
sp.p: Faith ſo am I.

lg.l: And I am ſorry too but cannot cry,
Now Is my plot made perfect, all the wheels
Are in a general motion, I muſt follow, I ſhall
Never think they are in priſon, till I ſee them
Within the Compter-gates.
My ſinging Gallants your mad miſdemeanor,
Shall bring you now to ſing the Compter tenor.

div.head: Scaena prima.
div.stage: Enter as in the Compter Wildblood, Rivers, Flylove, Mrs. Trimwel and Keeper.

sp.speaker: Wild.
sp.l: Blood of the Rivers, thou beginſt to droop,
Thy ſoul ſeems not ſo active as it was:
Where be thoſe capering pieces of pure flaſh,
That made the genius of the place grow Comick?
By the wanton memory of Chaucer I could turn Poet,
And write in as Heathen Engliſh; and as bawdy;
I'le not to bed to night.

sp.speaker: Rivers.
sp.p: Nor I by Jove.

sp.speaker: Fly.
sp.p: By Jupiter nor I, ſhall we be jovial; why ſhould we not; conceive this place a Tavern, one place may ſerve for two uſes; ſome conceive it the habitation of the ſorrowful, and our free ſpirits ſhall convert it to a Paradiſe of delight; Pray Sir what hour of the night is't.

sp.speaker: Keeper.
sp.p: Paſt twelve Sir.

sp.speaker: Fly.
sp.p: It is an age to morning:

sp.speaker: Frank Rivers,
sp.p: prethee cheer up the woman, ſhe droope.

sp.speaker: Riv.
sp.p: Doſt thou want reſt?

sp.speaker: Mrs. Trim.
sp.p: Yes Sir, far more then ſleep.

sp.speaker: Riv.
sp.l: Thy mind's diſquiet then, prethee be cheerful,
Sorrows are momentary as well as joyes;
Were I ith' bottome of the Ocean,
I'd bear my head up, till my own weight ſunk me.
Sir, can we have ſome Wine.

sp.speaker: Keep.
sp.p: I'le ring the Bell for you, they are up at the Feathers-Tavern; they lye at a ſafe Guard, they' I have their money before-hand.

sp.speaker: Fly.
sp.p: With all my heart, we ſhall not be miſ-reckoned then, here's money for a pottle of Canary, the night is ſomewhat cold, and Sack is ſprightly.

sp.speaker: Hugh.
sp.p: What a Hugh and cry you make, I have ſtayed up theſe two nights, you are all mad I think, will you not go to bed to night.

sp.speaker: Wild.
sp.p: Prethee honeſt Hugh (if thy name be ſo) fill us one pottle of Canary, let's have clean pipes and Tobacco.

sp.speaker: Hugh.
sp.p: Where's your money?

sp.speaker: Riv.
sp.p: At hand, at hand, my midnight Drawer.

sp.speaker: Hugh.
sp.p: Who's that, Mr. Rivers?

sp.speaker: Riv.
sp.p: I, doſt know me?

sp.speaker: Hugh.
sp.p: Do I Sir, I fill'd you many a gallon of Wine at the Bear upon Fleet-bridge.

sp.speaker: Riv.
sp.p: Oh, th'art an honeſt blade, I know thee, prethee fill me good Wine.

sp.speaker: Hugh.
sp.p: The beſt in the Sellar.

sp.speaker: Wil.
sp.p: Hark you ſir, is there not a French knight in the houſ?

sp.speaker: Keep.
sp.p: His name is Sir Reverence Lamard, he lies two ſtories higher to the ſtreet.

sp.speaker: Riv.
sp.p: A lamentable ſtory! can you not invite him down?

sp.speaker: Keep.
sp.p: I'le try Sir.

sp.speaker: Riv.
sp.p: Th'art an honeſt Keeper.

sp.speaker: Fly.
sp.p: Theſe Keepers have been rumor'd to be churliſh; I like this fellows humour very well.

sp.speaker: Wild.
sp.p: Oh what a crew of Wine-Leaches ſhal we have ſtick upon us to morrow morning for our Garniſh, we are of the Maſter-ſide, your half-crowns a piece Gentlemen, I know the order, I have commenc'd in this Colledge before now.

sp.speaker: Hugh.
sp.p: A pottle of Canary in the Compter, ſ •• re.

sp.speaker: Fly.
sp.p: In the Compter you rogue; Sir can't you ſhew us a better room.

sp.speaker: Hugh.
sp.p: It is too late Sir, pray be civill, and keep your own room:

sp.speaker: Fly.
sp.p: Is this the end of our travail? Here s a Health to our good deliverance.

sp.speaker: Wild.
sp.p: By the blood of Bacchus I'le pledge thee.

sp.speaker: Fly.
sp.p: Come I'le begin a mad Health, and let every man have his fancie.

l.hi: Here's a curſt to all thoſe
And from top to the toes
Till, be it ſpoke under the Roſe,

sp.speaker: Wild.
sp.p: Pray drink off your cup, and we'l all keep the cloſe, here comes my white Knight in his Lawn ſleeves, now if a Quaker ſaw him he would take his ſhirt for a Surpleſs, and condemn it for a Babyloniſh Garment, or in good ſooth and verily a wicked and ſuperſtitious remnant of that foul ſlaps the whore of Babylon.

sp.speaker: Sir Rev.
sp.p: Begar dat whore of Babylon be one of me Aunts.

sp.speaker: Riv.
sp.p: Monſieur you ſee we are come to bear you company, you ſhall not engroſs the priſon to your ſelf.

sp.speaker: Sir Rev.
sp.p: Me tank you for noting, you can no give me de ſheat now as you have frō (vat do you cal de fader of de pig)

sp.speaker: Fly.
sp.p: The father of the Pig; a Hog.

sp.speaker: Sir R.
sp.p: Hog, hog, hog, as you gave me de ſheat at Hogdown.

sp.speaker: Riv.
sp.p: Wel forget it, there was no hurt meant, on my credit, there was another cauſe you muſt not know.

sp.speaker: Sir R.
sp.p: Begar but me do know already, you carry away de Surzhons viſe, begar he be horn-mad.

sp.speaker: Wild.
sp.p: How came you to know this? would he reveal it?

sp.speaker: Sir R.
sp.p: Yes begar and more to, 'twas he dat make Drowzy de Kiſhin-wenſh to arreſt Monſieur Flylove.

sp.speaker: Riv.
sp.p: The devil at laſt is even with us.

sp.speaker: Within.
sp.p: Room for my Lord Judge.

sp.speaker: Fly.
sp.p: How now what's the matter?

sp.speaker: Keep.
sp.p: This noiſe is ith' Kings Ward; 'tis term'd the Hole.

sp.speaker: Fly.
sp.p: But are they allow'd to be ſo lowd there.

sp.speaker: Keep.
sp.l: We cannot check a Cuſtome they have us'd,
Which is when a new Priſoner firſt comes in,
They have a Scaene of mirth, where one is Judge,
And ſits a tryal upon life and death.

sp.speaker: Fly.
sp.p: May we not ſee them Sir.

sp.speaker: Keep.
sp.p: I have no priviledg to open Wards at this late hour oth' night, left ſome combuſtion happen amongſt the priſoners, which my ſtrength will be too weak to pacifie.

sp.speaker: Riv.
sp.p: My life for yours no danger Sir.

sp.speaker: Keep.
sp.p: Ye appear honeſt Gentlemen, and I'le truſt ye.

sp.speaker: Riv.
sp.p: Thank you Sir; come Monſieur wil you walk down.

sp.speaker: Sir R.
sp.p: Zhentlem me vill vait on you to morrow, but me mus com to bed; but me have anoder plot in my head begar.

sp.speaker: Fly.
sp.p: Wel Monſieur good night▪ take reſt, and ſleep ſecure.

sp.speaker: Sir R.
sp.p: Awee Monſieur tres humble ſerviteur.

div.head: Act. 4. Scaen. 2.
div.stage: Enter as in the Hole Wildfire, Lord Lowſ-proof, Steward Rentfree Conſtable-Lazy, and Chamberlain-Jaylbird.

sp.speaker: Rent.
sp.p: What is your name my friend?

sp.speaker: Lowſ.
sp.p: You muſt tell the Steward your name, you will be the ſooner entred a member of the Sheriffs-Basket, there is (my friend) a ſtrange miracle in our living, we never want meat yet keep continual faſt; and yet all that faſt, you may ſee by our Clothes we are looſe enough; we live in imitation of the Owls, we ſleep ith' day time, and revel all the night: Some beds we have for Gentlemen of quality, as my ſelf being the Lord, Steward Rentfree, Conſtable Lazy, and Chamberlain Jaylbird.

sp.speaker: Wildf.
sp.p: Gentlemen, I was a Page to a Knight that was a priſoner in this houſe Sir Rev. Lamard, my name is Wildfire.

sp.speaker: Lowſ.
sp.p: Prethee ſtand farther off, thou wilt melt me elſe.
