sp.speaker: Jayl.
sp.p: My Lord begins to hiſs.

sp.speaker: Lowſ.
sp.p: Gentlemen of the Kings Ward let us conſult upon the buſineſs, 'tis for the good of the Hole, and of the whole Houſe; let us for once be wiſer and honeſter then e'r we have been, there may come much miſchief by this Wildfire, if he ſtay long he will conſume us, and every creeping thing about us, our beds being all ſtraw is very combuſtible; the very blowing on's noſe blows a bed up.

sp.speaker: Rent.
sp.p: There's a Bug upon your Honours doublet.

sp.speaker: Lowſ.
sp.p: Is there but one, give it Wildfire, he is fit for nothing but to receive my Moabites in reverſion, they may live upon him like ſo many Salamanders; I will petition to morrow for the diſcharge of Wildfire, he ſhall not ſtay with us, we muſt have Wildfire put out, 'tis pity ſuch a ſpark ſhould be in the Compter.

div.stage: Enter Keeper, Flylove, Rivers, Wildblood, Mrs. Trimw.
div.p: Stand aſide, here comes the Gentlemen Rats, it is moſt fit I give them the firſt ſalutation; Gentlemen you are moſt unhappily incountred.

sp.speaker: Fly.
sp.p: I do moſt unfortunately thank you Sir, we come to ſee your Revels, are they ended? are you my Lord?

sp.speaker: Lazy.
sp.p: Yes Sir, he's my Lord.

sp.speaker: Fly.
sp.p: Well Gentlemen we make bold to viſit you, and (to be the better welcome) we have brought with us each man a bottle of Canary; who's that knocks?

sp.speaker: Keep.
sp.p: 'Tis ſomebody at the Compter-gate, ſome more Rats I believe.

sp.speaker: Wild.
sp.p: Bring them hither of what degree ſoever.

sp.speaker: Lazy.
sp.p: I, I, Hole 'um, Hole 'um; Rat, tat, tat, this is the City-Mouſ-trap; here do we lye at a ſure ward, revel all night, and breath defiance to the Watch and the Conſtable; we have ſuffered under the terrour of Authority, and now we have got the Law in our own hands.

sp.speaker: Lowzy.
sp.p: A Rat, a Rat, a Rat.

sp.speaker: Riv.
sp.p: What are they, Citizens or Gentlemen?

sp.speaker: Low.
sp.p: No, no, they are neither Citizens nor Gentlemen, and yet they are a company for Lords, they are muſicall Rats, ſinging Rats, men that are come to keep time in the Compter; they are crowding in, therefore you that mean to expreſs your activity, prepare and be in readineſs, a man in priſon may eaſily do his ſink-a-pace.

sp.speaker: Fly.
sp.p: Theſe are the Blades that were with us at Hogsdon; this was ſome preciſe Conſtable, ſome brother oth' Family, that ſent the Muſicians to priſon, or elſe ſome joviall Humouriſt that had a mind the priſoners ſhould be merry to night; well my Maſters, ſince you are here, ſtrike up couragiouſly, here be Gentlemen have a mind to diſcover their footing, you ſhall not loſe your labour, I'le pay your Fees in the morning.

sp.speaker: Fidlers.
sp.p: We thank you noble Mr. Flylove.

sp.speaker: Low.
sp.p: Gentlemen, throw of your bottomleſs pantoffles, and let's to't, here's Sack to cherriſh us when we have finiſhed.

sp.speaker: Wildb.
sp.p: Gentlemen, we thank you, when we'r at liberty, we'l ſend you ſomething worth your eſtimation, in the mean time drink that.

sp.speaker: Fly.
sp.p: I come, let's go, I do not like the fume of this cloſe room; how fare you Mrs. Trimwel?

sp.speaker: Mrs. Trim.
sp.p: Well Sir, but that the ſcent is ſomewhat noyſome, the room above, from whence we came, is ſweeter.

sp.speaker: Riv.
sp.p: Come, we'l go up agen then.

sp.speaker: Fly.
sp.p: I, I, let's go, god-night good friends.

sp.speaker: Omnes.
sp.p: We thank you Gentlemen, we'l drink your healths to morrow morning.

sp.speaker: Riv.
sp.p: In the morning Muſick we'l keep our words with you, but I ſhall talk with you for the trick you put upon me at Hogsdon.

sp.speaker: Fidlers.
sp.p: It was no fault of ours indeed Mr. Rivers, we'l mak't appear to morrow.
sp.stage: Exeunt Rivers, Mrs. Trim. Wildblood and Flylove.

sp.speaker: Riv.
sp.p: Well, well, good night.

sp.speaker: Omnes.
sp.p: Good night to you all Gentlemen.

sp.speaker: Lowſ.
sp.p: Come my Maſters we that were Dancers will make an equal diviſion of the Gentlemans bounty, here is ten ſhillings, and we are ſix on's.

sp.speaker: Ren.
sp.p: 12. d. a piece, & the reſt in drink among the priſners

sp.speaker: Lowſ.
sp.p: I like the motion well my equal Steward, here is ſome Sack left, that we'l drink with the Muſitians, and excuſe their Garniſh in the morning.

sp.speaker: Omnes.
sp.p: Agreed, agreed.

sp.speaker: Lowſ.
sp.p: Let us conſult farther in our with-drawing room: How now Chamberlain cannot you leave your old trade? muſt you be filching? wouldſt thou undo a poor Commonwealth at one pull thou unconſcionable thief, but I am too ſubtil for you ſirrah, you can't deceive me; The devil take me if my Angel leave me.

sp.speaker: Rent.
sp.p: Nobly ſpoke my Lord; room for my Lord there.

div.stage: Enter above with a long rope Sir Rev. Lamard.

sp.speaker: Sir Rev.
sp.p: 'Tis very light, begar me ſall be diſcover; now if my ſtring do ſlip, down goes Sir Reverence upon ſome Waſh-mans head, and begar dat vill bewray all; I can ſee noting but de Fiddles in de Priſon; if I ſall break my neck in ſundra for my liberty, begar my adverſary make dice of my bones, but I ſall couzen him, for my bone crumble to aſhes: So, ſo, vas very faſt, and ſo faſt, as me can, me vill down; Begar me tink it be ſomewhat ſtrange dat me mus come to be ſave by de Rope, but if I be taken, for ought I know I ſall be hang in de Rope. I care not me ſall He ſlides down and reſteth on the Feathers Tavern. ventre for all dat, as good be hang as live in priſon: Begar here comes ſombody vith light, me ſall be taken, dere Ent. Pimpw. drunk with a Torch in his hand. be no vay to ſcape, and me canot clime up agen: Oh Diabolo vat ſall become of me, de vindow be ſhut, me can no creep into de Tavern, and I ſall not be taken for Zhorge a horſ-back, as me ſaw once in de Play; begar dis man be drunk, I ſee by his ſtagger.

sp.speaker: Pimpw.
sp.p:
A ſawcy Conſtable to queſtion my lodging, cannot a man go home to his houſe in peace? Is it not ſufficient that I can carry my ſelf to the Compter, but I muſt be beholding to an enigmatical Conſtable, and his miſchievous
Watch; a man can no ſooner come neer them, but who goes there? come before the Conſtable; Come afore a Cuckold, Oh ſuch a rogue would be hang'd; Let me ſee, where am I? this is Woodſtreet, whereabouts is the Feathers-Tavern.

sp.speaker: Sir Rev.
sp.p: A pox for you, you be too neer de Feder-Tavern already, and begar now I ſee him, dis fellow be priſoner in de Compter, but I have an invention he ſall no ſpy me, begar me vill creep into dis Buſh, and ven he be gone me ſall go down courageo.

sp.speaker: Pimpw.
sp.p: This is the Compter where many a man lies with a heavy heart, I have been a priſoner this two or three years, yet I walk abroad at my leaſure, and am as drunk as a devil for my pleaſure.

sp.speaker: Sir Rev.
sp.p: Begar me have extream need to make vater, I ſall piſh my breeſh, Oh Diabolo I ſall be found, begar me can ſtay no longra, me ſall burſe.

sp.speaker: Pimpw.
sp.p: I will knock up this rogue Hugh at the Feathers; Hugh, Hugh, you rogue riſe, my name's Pimpwel, you ſleepy rogue riſe and let me in, muſt I wait upon you with a pox to you. Nouns what's that?

sp.speaker: Sir Rev.
sp.p: Begar now I be undon in a piſſing vhile.

sp.speaker: Pimpw.
sp.p: You ſon of a Batchelor, do you throw your Piſpots upon my head, if I could finde ſtones I'de break your windows, but ſince I cannot, I will even make bold to ſet fire of your Buſh, then throw your water and ſpare not.

sp.speaker: Sir Rev.
sp.p: Oh Mordieu, me ſall be burn in de Buſh, or be hang in de Rope, I vould I were in me ſhamber agen.

sp.speaker: Pimpw.
sp.p: What's here, a Rope? ſome priſoner Pimpw. ſpieth the rope. has made an eſcape out of the Maſters-ſide; there's money for ſomebody to pay, I'le in and call the Turn-key, a priſoner eſcap't, a priſoner, a priſoner.

sp.speaker: Within.
sp.p: From whence?

sp.speaker: Pimpw.
sp.p: A private chamber in the Maſters-ſide.

sp.speaker: Within.
sp.p: A priſoner, a priſoner.

sp.speaker: Pimpw.
sp.p: Look, look, here's the Rope.

sp.speaker: Keep.
sp.p: Run up to the Maſters-ſide, ſee if the French Knight be in's Chamber, his Action is 6000. l. we are all undone if he eſcape away.

sp.speaker: Pimpw.
sp.p: I, I, we are all undone, if he be gone here's Rope enough for us all.

sp.speaker: 3. Keep.
sp.p: Pox on you for a drunken rogue, wher haſt bin?

sp.speaker: Pimpw.
sp.p: Drinking wine in bowls boys, I am almoſt drunk, but what ſhal we do for the priſoner, ſhall I run after him?

sp.speaker: 3. Keep.
sp.p: Which way is he gone?

sp.speaker: Pim.
sp.p: The Lord knows.

sp.speaker: 2. Keep.
sp.p: Hallowgh?

sp.speaker: 1. Keep.
sp.p: What ſay you?

sp.speaker: 2. Keep.
sp.p: The French Knight is eſcaped, you muſt make ſwift purſuit, he cannot be gone far.

sp.speaker: 1. Keep.
sp.p: Pluck up the Rope; look well toth' Gate, Pimpwel run you to Cripplegate, you to ſome other Watches, and all the way you run, cry out a priſoner.

sp.speaker: 3. Keep.
sp.p: A priſoner, a priſoner.

div.stage: Sir Reverence comes out of the Buſh.

sp.speaker: Sir Rev.
sp.p: Oh the great pox run with you all, vat a fear have dey put me in, begar me vill not ſtay, 'tis very light, I ſee no paſſenger, dis vas de braveſt time: So, now me are down, futra for Keeper; begar me can no ſhuſe but laugh, how dey run-away from me to find me; Oh me brave buſh! Fiſh vay ſall me take to be ſafe, me mus come no neer Cripplegate, nor Sheapſide, I ſall take ſome udder vay, the devil is in me if I come agen; Farewell good Compter, I am not loath to part from you: I remember two line of an Engliſhman dat vent from de Priſon, dey var des:

l.hi: Dis Houſe mus be let at a miſerable rate,
For I ha' left my Shambra, any man may ha't.

sp.p: Farewel Comptera.

sp.speaker: Splend.
sp.p: Can you direct me to the hapleſs lodging of yong

sp.speaker: Keep.
sp.p: He lies ith' Maſters-ſide, he is a Gentleman whoſe miſery works much compaſſion in each Officer, I would my power could ſave him.

sp.speaker: Splend.
sp.l: Thank you Sir?
Such worthy wiſhes in ſuch men as you,
Who bear a function of that cruel nature,
Being ſo rare, appears moſt excellent;
Pray tell me Sir, how doth he take his ſufferings?

sp.speaker: Keep.
sp.l: I think he is in love; he's often heard
To ſigh a Ladies name, and ſing ſad Sonnets
In diſſolving paſſion,
Such as might melt the Tyger-cruelty
Of men turn'd Tyrants; thus much I obſerve,
The priſon doth not fright him from his reſt,
Like his divorce from her whoſe name he ſighs ſo;
I'le call him if you pleaſe, yet 'tis ſomewhat early.

sp.speaker: Splend.
sp.l: Sir, I give thanks
Unto your loving diligence, and with your leave,
I ſhall conceive it but a friendly Office,
To ſpare his labour, and walk up to him.

sp.speaker: Keep.
sp.p: Thoſe ſtayrs direct you, turn on your left hand.

sp.speaker: Bella.
sp.p: Are you the Keeper Sir?

sp.speaker: Keep.
sp.l: I turn the key, my Office is as much
To let men out as in; I take no pride,
To ſtand 'twixt men and freedome, ſuck a Keeper
I am, and would be thought.

sp.speaker: Bella.
sp.p: Heaven be thy Keeper, and grant thy place corrupt thee not; pray Sir, was there not brought in amongſt other Gentlemen, a priſoner late laſt night, call'd Mr. Flylove?

sp.speaker: Keep.
sp.p: Yes Lady.

sp.speaker: Bella.
sp.p: How could I ſpeak a word in private with him? the buſineſs which I have concerns his freedome.

sp.speaker: Keep.
sp.p: I ſhall be glad to call him, — Mr. Flylove.

sp.speaker: Priſoners within.
sp.p: Mr. Flylove, Mr. Flylove.

sp.speaker: Fly.
sp.p: What a noiſe you make, I'm become a man of calling now; who is't would ſpeak with me Sir.

sp.speaker: Keep.
sp.p: Here's a fair Lady, I'le leave you to your opportunity.

sp.speaker: Fly.
sp.p: Gramercy honeſt Keeper: How now, who's this? How my blood ſtartles in me on the ſudden?

sp.speaker: Bella.
sp.p: What, do I fright you Sir? I come to ſee and comfort you with my beſt love to file your Fetters off.

sp.speaker: Fly.
sp.l: Such charitable language, and ſuch face
Had beauteous Bellaflora, to whoſe ſoul
Mine was contracted, but my breach of vow,
Joyn'd with the infamy of this Ioath'd action,
So lately done, hath ſent her far from me;
This is the pleaſant widdow we met at Hogsdon,
I remember now;
But ſee how guilt will fool a man, I was
Admiring how you thought to finde me here.

sp.speaker: Bella.
sp.l: Some other time I'le tell you, if I may
(Without the breach of modeſt manners) ask you
What is the cauſe of your impriſonment?

sp.speaker: Fly.
sp.p: What a queſtion's that? I'le lye ith' Compter all my life time, e're I make known the cauſe that laid me here, a toy, a trifle, for nothing but diſputing with the Conſtable, here's Jack, Wildblood and Frank Rivers in the houſe (three merry boys be we) here's the woman too, will you go ſee them.

sp.speaker: Bella.
sp.p: No Sir, but if the cauſe of your reſtraint from freedom be of that eaſie value, you'l be gone within an hour.

sp.speaker: Fly.
sp.p: I, I, within this hour at the fartheſt.

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.l: Poor man, how thou deceiv'ſt me and thy ſelf,
I as much bluſh to let him underſtand
I know the cauſe of his affliction,
As he doth to reveal it; if you pleaſe
I'le ſtay till you go off.

sp.speaker: Fly.
sp.p: You may ſtay this twelve-month for ought aſide I know; I muſt put her off, to ſay the plain truth Lady I have an Action entred againſt me ſince I came in.

sp.speaker: Bella.
sp.p: You need not let that fright you, I have ſo much skill, although a very unexperienc'd woman to tell you, whilſt you are under the command of any Juſtice for the breach oth' peace, you are not lyable to any Action.

sp.speaker: Fly.
sp.p: She ſays true, where the Devil got you ſo much law?

sp.speaker: Bella.
sp.p: Come, come, I know the cauſe that keeps you here.

sp.speaker: Fly.
sp.p: How! I am ſorry for that.

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: Is't not a womans Action?

sp.speaker: Fly.
sp.p: A womans Action.

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: I have hit the mark, and I could name the party.

sp.speaker: Fly.
sp.p: Lady I'le take my leave, I'm call'd above.

sp.speaker: Bella.
sp.l: Indeed you are not Sir, pray ſtay a little,
I know you think the fact you have committed,
To be of that vile nature, that you bluſh
To tell or think I know it; you the leſs
Stand in my condemnation for the ill,
Becauſe 'twas acted on ſo much deformity,
It makes me think ſome Witchcraft, drink, or madneſs
Poſſeſt you at that time; they being remov'd,
Your penitence brings back your raviſht worth,
And you are man agen, but the nice winner
Of every fair one's a judicious ſinner,
And in that judgement multiplies each fact,
And findes his Tragedy in the laſt Act.

sp.speaker: Fly.
sp.p: This circumſtance confirms your knowledge of it, And I am ſorry.

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: That I know't.

sp.speaker: Fly.
sp.p: Tis true.

sp.speaker: Bella.
sp.l: But if you pleaſe't ſhan't be the worſe for you,
Would I were beautiful enough to pleaſe you,
Or had a mind that you might think ſo fair,
To merit your beſt wiſhes in the bliſs
Of ſacred Wedlock, you ſhould then be ſure
To ſhake this bondage off.

sp.speaker: Fly.
sp.l: Pray let me pauſe.
My former raſhneſs may take licenſe for't;
I am in priſon, and the Law exacts
My body for a year; I could produce
Such bayl as is ſufficient for my freedom,
But I will periſh e'r I reveal my ſcandall;
This woman's fair, and hath a face ſo like
To one, whoſe memory I owe my being,
I know not what to anſwer; Then agen
'Tis for my freedom, from a bondage which
May ruine ſoul and body; I'm reſolv'd,
If Bellaflora knew it, ſo would ſhe,
And pardon all, which works my Liberty.
You do not ask me this to try me, do you?

sp.speaker: Bella.
sp.p: No by thoſe joys I wiſh for.

sp.speaker: Fly.
sp.l: Nor tell me of my fact, or of your friendſhip,
At every angry occaſion,
Which the beſt married pair ſeldome avoid.

sp.speaker: Bella.
sp.l: May all my life be made of diſcontents,
And they in old age kill me, if I do:

lg.l: How neer ſhe comes to Bellaflora ſtill,
In all her noble actions; If I could
Believe the Pythagorean axioms true,
Of tranſmigrated ſpirits, did the Grave
Contain my Bellaflora, I ſhould think
This frame contain'd her ſoul, the Gods would ſure
Conſume me, if this Contract I now make
And ſeal, this vertuous woman were not lawful:
By all the joys eternal, by the hopes
I have to live a life that's long and bleſt,
To ſee a numerous iſſue fairly bred
In all their actions, ſhewing ſtill the minds
Of their long ſleeping Anceſtors, I'le bee
Thy husband, love, and life, I'le marry thee.

sp.speaker: Bella.
sp.p: This day.

sp.speaker: Fly.
sp.p: This very day.

sp.speaker: Within.
sp.p: Stephen Flylove, the Conſtable's come.

sp.speaker: Keep.
sp.p: Sir, the Conſtable waits for you.

sp.speaker: Bella.
sp.p: Delay not, ith' mean time I'le bayle you here, Remember Sir.

sp.speaker: Fly.
sp.p: I doe.

sp.speaker: Bella.
sp.p: Adieu my dear.

div.head: Scaena prima.
div.stage: Enter Flyl. Bellafl. Rivers, Mrs. Trimwel and Wildblood.

sp.speaker: Wild.
sp.l: W • lcome to liberty my Cavaliers,
The gawdy portalIs of the red-cheekt morn,
Stand wide to entertain you, and delight
Your ſickned ſences with the bright diſplay
Of glittering Phoebus.

sp.speaker: Rivers.
sp.p: Your genius ſoars too high, you'l melt his wings.

sp.speaker: Wild.
sp.l: I am aiery as Philetus when he tripp'd
Over the ears of Corn, and ne'r bent head;
I could out-run Atlanta.

sp.speaker: Rivers.
sp.l: Atlanta? within theſe two hours a Cripple could
out-run thee, and give thee five in the fifteen:
But Stephen, why ſo ſtupid? rowſe thy ſpirit;
Can Liberty diſcomfort, or the exchange
Of grates for fragrant fields diſmay thee thus.

sp.speaker: Fly.
sp.p: Faith I am dull, and I ha' reaſon for't.

sp.speaker: Wild.
sp.p: What is the melancholly matter prethee?

sp.speaker: Fly.
sp.p: That which will move you all when I ſhall ſpeak; Mercurio's dead.

sp.speaker: Rivers.
sp.p: Dead!

sp.speaker: Wild.
sp.p: He was well laſt night.

sp.speaker: Fly.
sp.p: He dy'd this morning.

sp.speaker: Wild.
sp.p: Oh my poor loſt friend!

sp.speaker: Rivers.
sp.p: His cruel Creditor is paid; Oh my Mercurio!

sp.speaker: Fly.
sp.l: I knew 'twould dull you all as well as I,
This day his Funeral is, I hope you'l be
The ſad ſpectators of his Obſequies,
Raynard the Keeper will inſtruct you when,
And tell you more, pray go and leave me here,
I have a ſadneſs that concerns not you,
I'le put it off and meet ye.

sp.speaker: Riv.
sp.p: Good morrow Stephen.

sp.speaker: Wild.
sp.p: Farewel friend.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Trim.
sp.p: Good morrow Mr. Flyl.

sp.speaker: Fly.
sp.p: Your humble ſervant; Laday what ſtay you for?

sp.speaker: Bella.
sp.p: Where would you have me be?

sp.speaker: Fly.
sp.p: Where you pleaſe; I can't command your being.

sp.speaker: Bella.
sp.l: What means my Love?
Your ſpeech betrays ſome diſcontent in you.

sp.speaker: Fly.
sp.p: Yes, I'm troubled, Oh my ſweet Bellaflora!

sp.speaker: Bella.
sp.p: Who do you ſigh for Sir?

sp.speaker: Fly.
sp.p: A friend, a friend, an honeſt friend of mine.

sp.speaker: Bella.
sp.p: This is a time to baniſh diſcontents.

sp.speaker: Fly.
sp.p: No, no, to increaſe them.

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: It is an hour was made to conſecrate our holy contract

sp.speaker: Fly.
sp.p: Why I, I told you ſo.

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: Will you not marry me.

sp.speaker: Fly.
sp.l: I will not break my faith to Bellaflora
To gain a Queen, a Goddeſs.

sp.speaker: Bella.
sp.p: Then you have plighted faith unto another.

sp.speaker: Fly.
sp.p: Yes cunning temptreſs I have.

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.l: Why do you blemiſh my well-meaning heart,
With ſuch a title?

sp.speaker: Fly.
sp.l: Could your ſecurer ſubtilty preſume
On no deceit but this? Had you propos'd
Out of ſome Magazine of rarities,
Gold, Silver, Jewels, • hough they were as precious
As Erephile's Bracelet (which ſhe ſold
Her dear affecting husband for) I had
Eſteem'd them all as nothing, but weak I
Too fond of (what I now curſe) Liberty,
Muſt ſell my peace, my life, and much I fear
My bliſs eternal.

sp.speaker: Bella.
sp.l: Oh you Angels, where
Lives there a faithful man, why did you make
This ſolemn Contract to me.

sp.speaker: Fly.
sp.l: 'Twas a bad proteſtation, and the breach
Is better then performance, yet becauſe
You ſhall not ſay I cheated favours from you,
Reſign me to my priſon, where I'le live,
Onely with thinking of my Bellaflora,
Her very name ſhall purifie the ayre,
And make a dungeon grow as fragrant,
As Meadow Flowers in triumphant June.

sp.speaker: Bella.
sp.l: Thou common man that doſt two contracts break,
I have ſo much to ſay, I cannot ſpeak.

sp.speaker: Fly.
sp.l: Like men for Robberies that loſe their breath,
I leave the priſon to embrace my death.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Trim.
sp.p: You are very wanton Frank.

sp.speaker: Rivers.
sp.l: Now I have got thee ſingle, ſhall we try
An amorous duell for a boy now, I'm all fire,
And could perform an act 'bove Hercules;
Glue thy red lips to mine, and let us prove,
The jocund pleaſure of the billing Dove.
Agen, once more, you do not do it heartily,
We'l make a numeration from a kiſs,
Shall poſe Arithmatick.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Trim.
sp.p: You'l tell of this.

sp.speaker: Riv.
sp.p: Steal, and reveal; he's a bold thief indeed.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Trim.
sp.l: There are too many ſuch.
They cannot have a favour, — ſuch a one.

sp.speaker: Rivers.
sp.p: I, ſuch a one.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Trim.
sp.l: As you imagine, but they muſt reveal it,
As if it were a ſecond ſporf to tell it.

sp.speaker: Rivers.
sp.l: They glory in their actions, and would prove
How much they merit by their Ladies love;
This I diſdain.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Trim.
sp.p: Do ye uſe to talk in your ſleep, you'l tell it to your bed-fellow.

sp.speaker: Riv.
sp.p: You are too jealous of me.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Trim.
sp.l: Come then, I'le try thee; kiſs me,
That's the firſt peal to bed, but I won't truſt ye.

sp.speaker: Rivers.
sp.p: Why do you mock me thus?

sp.speaker: Mrs. Trim.
sp.l: The cauſe being ſo great, I may be doubtful,
You'l have another Love, then out goes all,
But uſe your will.

sp.speaker: Rivers.
sp.p: To do thy will a pleaſure, ſhall we be private.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Trim.
sp.p: As private as you pleaſe.

sp.speaker: Rivers.
sp.p: Such privacie beſt pleaſeth.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Trim.
sp.p: Come let's away then.

sp.speaker: Rivers.
sp.p: Stay (upon better thought) I have Riv. returns. No ſuch deſire to't.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Trim.
sp.p: How?

sp.speaker: Riv.
sp.p: Prethee be not angry, I am very loath to go to hell ſo eaſily.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Trim.
sp.p: What pretty change is this?

sp.speaker: Riv.
sp.p: I would it pleas'd you, pray ſatisfie one thought and I am for you.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Trim.
sp.p: Willingly.

sp.speaker: Riv.
sp.p: And truly.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Trim.
sp.p: By my life I will.

sp.speaker: Riv.
sp.l: Did never ſilken Gallant with queint words,
A fair proportion'd body, and ſmooth chin,
Such as you women like, tempt you to this,
This feat, before I mov'd you.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Trim.
sp.p: Never.

sp.speaker: Riv.
sp.p: Never, prethee bethink thy ſelf, you doubt me ſtill.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Trim.
sp.p: But you ſuſpect me more, I vow never.

sp.speaker: Riv.
sp.l: How fain would I believe thee, if thou ſwear'ſt true,
Thou'rt fitter far for Heaven then this act,
Which thou ſhalt ne'r be guilty of for me;
What pitty 'tis to take fair new blancht Lawn,
And ſprinkle ink on't; let not your husbands doubts,
Bred by your frequent abſence, and ſuch howers
Civility ne'r warranted, urge you
To acts that cauſe his ſhame, and your own ſhame.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Trim.
sp.p: Whats' your intent for this.

sp.speaker: Riv.
sp.l: I'le tel you.
The guilty giddy people, who conceive
All acts more vile then they appear,
Have ſpred an infamy upon us both,
Which if unquell'd, in time will fix a ſtain,
(though cauſleſs) which no Rethorick can charm
To alteration; thus in brief I'le do,
By a moſt queint invention I have thought,
I ſhall return you to your husband, who
Shall with his love, not jealouſie, embrace you,
And to the bold ears of the rumorous world,
Declare his errour, and your innocence.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Trim.
sp.l: A very modeſt way to do me miſchief,
I thank you for your love, your honeſt love.

sp.speaker: Rivers.
sp.p: That you'l confeſs hereafter, will you go?

sp.speaker: Mrs. Trim.
sp.l: Yes Sir, I'le wait on you;
Am I betray'd by tricks? a Letter op'd,
The ſecret read, and then ſeal'd up agen?
Inquiſitive fool, thy dear experience ſhall
Inſtruct thee, what a fate he undergoes,
That turns the fierce ſtream of a womans love:
I could be leſs impatient had he ſpoke
From knowledge of my guilt, then know my will,
And afterwards diſcloſe me; well I'le diſguiſe my anger,
And frame a fierce revenge ſhall make thee tremble,
Women act miſchief ſure when they diſſemble.

div.head: Act. 3. Scaen. 2.

sp.speaker: Nice.
sp.p: Is the French Knight in priſon, what is his debt?

sp.speaker: Splen.
sp.p: Six thouſand pound they ſay Sir.

sp.speaker: Nice.
sp.l: Tis a great ſum I have been wrong enform'd,
'Twas credibly reported on the Change,
He had a free eſtate, his Traffick great,
A moſt unqueſtion'd credit; and doth all
Conclude in this, they did not mean me well
That tempted my belief thus.

sp.speaker: Splend.
sp.p: Shall my ſuit have gracious hearing yet Sir?

sp.speaker: Nice.
sp.l: What for Mercurio?
Becauſe I was ſo neer to be deceiv'd,
With the feign'd riches of a Bankerupt,
Would you betray your ſelf to certain beggery.

sp.speaker: Splen.
sp.l: Will you be pleas'd to free him from his bondage?
It is reported he is ſick, that place
Will kill him, where is then your ſatisfaction?

sp.speaker: Nice.
sp.l: He cannot want a friend for twenty pound,
I will not loſe my money, I'le take time,
If he can fit me with ſecurity.

sp.speaker: Splen.
sp.p: Alas he is not able.

div.stage: Enter Mercurio on a Hearſe, four Bearers (as Mourners) Wild. Riv. Flyl. Mrs. Trim. Raynard, Pimpwel. They ſet the Coffin before Nice, and Flylove makes an Oration.

sp.speaker: Nice.
sp.l: What are theſe; heark you friend, whoſe body's this?
And whither carry you it?

sp.speaker: Fly.
sp.l: Here Sir our journey ends,
It is the body of deceas'd Mercurio,
A priſoner at your ſuit, who dyed this morning,
And thus according to an ancient cuſtome,
We bear him to you (all that's left)
His bones to make you ſatisfaction,
Becauſe his poverty enforc'd him (living)
To keep your right from you; withall, our form
Is to deliver to the Creditor,
At whoſe peculiar ſuit the debtor dyes,— A bale of Dice.

sp.speaker: Nice.
sp.p: Strange cuſtom; Heaven! now it doth amaze me.

sp.speaker: Fly.
sp.l: I have a little ſpeech that muſt excuſe
The expences of a bought Oration, which concerns
His miſerable end, and cauſe of it, and I have done.

sp.speaker: Splen.
sp.p: Oh my Mercurio.

sp.speaker: Riv.
sp.p: Look to the Lady.

sp.speaker: Fly.
sp.l: When he came in he wanted all that makes
Man in this Age ſubſtantial (Friends and Coyn)
Which want was ſoon attended with theſe, neglect & hunger
But then the perturbations of his minde,
His ſighing ſilence onely could declare,
As if they were too vaſt for elocution;
Great griefs are tongue-ty'd, there's no clamour rear'd,
So deepeſt waters crawl along unheard.

sp.speaker: Nice.
sp.l: Moſt reverend piece of ſorrow, whoſe wet eyes
Drop, as they would command another Spring,
To raiſe the body from its earthly ruine,
To heat and life agen; what friendſhip had you with him?

sp.speaker: Fly.
sp.l: Sir, I am one,
That wiſh I had ſuch neerneſs to his vertue,
As to his blood; a poor unhappy Kinſman.

sp.speaker: Nice.
sp.l: There's ſo much Magick in your ſorrow Sir,
All my attentions charm'd.

sp.speaker: Fly.
sp.l: Like men who are neer drowning, catch weak hold
On broken boords, on ſedge, or any thing
Diſaſtrous chance betrays to the wild waves,
He ſends for me that could but grieve his ſight,
With the wet ſorrow in my eyes for him:
Inſtead of Chambers hung with Tapeſtry,
Arras, and Attick pictures, the dark walls
Are eaſly beautifi'd with Chalk and Cole,
According to the melancholly fancy
Of the ſad Priſoners, where the numerous beds
Shew like ſo many Graves in a Churchyard,
With the men riſing out: No Canopies
But what the charitable Spider wove,
To ſave their always watching eyes from danger,
For they'r un-us'd to ſleep.

sp.speaker: Nice.
sp.p: Alas poor men.

sp.speaker: Fly.
sp.l: In ſuch a ſtate as this my kinſman lay,
My poor, poor kinſman.

sp.speaker: Nice.
sp.p: Thou weep'ſt too faſt old man, I ſhal not overtake thee.

sp.speaker: Fly.
sp.l: I figh'd, ſate down by him, and did obſerve
The manner of his Chamber-mates, and one
Belov'd above the reſt, as it appear'd,
Was cheriſht with a friend that happy day,
Who ſaid he came to ſee him, could not ſtay,
Although ſome Meſſenger fix times had been
To fetch him, but in vain, was ne'r within
After he heard the buſineſs, though his eare
Was within hearing of the Meſſenger:
At laſt he was within, without all doubt,
Becauſe he heard the priſoners going out,
Gives him a ſhilling, bids him have good cheer,
He was glad to ſee him, ſorry to ſee him here,
And ſo he parts, proteſting for to come,
He knows not when, this is his wretched doom
Of undone debtors, and my kinſmans Tomb.

sp.speaker: Nice.
sp.l: Since bleeding cleanſeth veins, I hope to finde
Th'expence of tears will purifie the minde:
What is this writing Sir?

sp.speaker: Fly.
sp.l: 'Tis his own hand,
One hour befor his death he writ Epitaph.

sp.speaker: Nice.
sp.p: With his own hand? pray read it.

sp.speaker: Fly.
sp.p: I ſhall Sir.

lg.head: EPITAPH.
lg.l: I which once with life did move,
Here lye Coffin'd up, to prove
Till death I was Splendora's Love.
I that have with many groans,
And wet eyes waſht the priſon ſtones,
For want of Money, pay my bones.
Let none with exclamation call,
Upon my name, and ſcorn my fall,
I ow'd but little, and paid all.

sp.speaker: Nice.
sp.l: Thou haſt paid all indeed, thy breath and all,
Iſ't were no fin I could beſtow a wiſh,
That life would viſit theſe cold corps agen.

sp.speaker: Fly.
sp.l: Where ſhall we bury him Sir, the cuſtome is
To bury men in debt ith' New-Churchyard;
Shall we diſpoſe him there?

sp.speaker: Nice.
sp.l: No, ſince he's dead he ſhall be well interr'd,
Though half my eſtate waſte for it, I have cauſe,
He lov'd Splendora, poor Girl ſhe'l dye too;
To your charge I commit this forty pound,
To provide mourning; I'le have Surgeons ſtrait,
That ſhall embalm the body.

sp.speaker: Fly.
sp.l: You ſhew your ſelf a noble Gentleman,
Whoſe memory we'l pray for; here Frank diſpatch.

sp.speaker: Rivers.
sp.p: It ſhall be done.

sp.speaker: Fly.
sp.l: Sir, here be Gentlemen that lov'd him, are
Willing to expreſs their loves, they have a Dirge.

sp.speaker: Nice.
sp.p: They are welcom, I'le attend their ceremony▪

stage.l: FRom ſelling, or from mortgaging of Lands,
From turning over goods in others hands,
And from the ſetting of our marks to bands.
From cruelty that keeps good men in awe,
From Serjeants, and ſuch Griffins of the Law,
And from the chattering of an Yeild-hall Daw.
From living at a miſerable rate,
In priſon where all people are ingrate;
And from the Porters at the Compter gate.
From being dragg'd in there with cruel gripes,
By an old curſed Catchpole called Tripes,
From paying for our Candles and our Pipes,
Next from the Stocks, the Hole, and Little-eaſe,
Sad places, which kind Nature do diſpleaſe,
And from the ratling of the Keepers Keys,

sp.speaker: Fly.
sp.p: Is all perform'd?

sp.speaker: Riv.
sp.p: To a tittle, here's a diſcharge from the Office.

sp.speaker: Fly.
sp.l: Then riſe from thy dead ſleep thou man of care,
Thy debt is paid, there's joyful news for thee.

sp.speaker: Nice.
sp.p: Am I deluded,

sp.speaker: Fly.
sp.l: Not a jot, come old man embrace him for your ſon,
Though he be poor, he is a Gentleman, and meritorious.

sp.speaker: Splend.
sp.p: But art thou living?

sp.speaker: Nice.
sp.p: I, you know it well enough, you ſhall even go together for your plots, I have paid my ſelf it ſeems.

sp.speaker: Rivers.
sp.p: Your Money lies ith' Office Sir.

sp.speaker: Nice.
sp.p: 'Tis very well, who comes here?

sp.speaker: Wild.
sp.p: Ware ho! here comes a mad man.

sp.speaker: Trim.
sp.l: Yes, a horn-mad man, Myruon are you there?
And your Sweetheart Rivers, I muſt part you;
Unhand him impudence.

sp.speaker: Riv.
sp.p: Sir, if you lay a violent hand on her, I touch your heart.

sp.speaker: Trim.
sp.l: Gentlemen, Is there law or conſcience in this?
To keep a mans wife, as they ſay, in ſpight on's teeth.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Trim.
sp.p: F. Rivers is more kind then I expected,

sp.speaker: Rivers.
sp.l: Your jealouſie hath wrackt her vertuous name,
And by my life ſhe's free from actual ill.
As e're thy mother was.

sp.speaker: Mrs Trim.
sp.p: He'l ne'r believe you,

sp.speaker: Rivers.
sp.l: No, he ſhall I warrant you,
E're I commit her to your curſed uſage,
I'l ſee ſome reformation of your life.

sp.speaker: Trim.
sp.p: You'l ſee't.

sp.speaker: Rivers.
sp.l: Yes Sir, I'le ſee't.
My Mothers daughter ſhall not be expos'd
Unto your giddy humors.

sp.speaker: Trim.
sp.p: Your Mothers daughter?

sp.speaker: Riv.
sp.p: Yes Sir, my Siſter.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Trim.
sp.p: What trick is this?

sp.speaker: Trim.
sp.p: Pray what may I call your name Sir.

sp.speaker: Rivers.
sp.l: I never fear'd it, though I have diſguis'd it,
For ſome ends which beſt concern my ſelf,
Before I went to France, men that would know
By my own name to call me, call'd me Brooks.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Trim.
sp.p: My brother Frederick?

sp.speaker: Rivers.
sp.p: The ſame Siſter; I muſt talk with you.

sp.speaker: Trim.
sp.p: Oh, my ſhame! Brother I hope you'l forgive me.

sp.speaker: Rivers.
sp.p: This is no time nor place for our contention.

sp.speaker: Nice.
sp.p: Who comes here?

sp.speaker: Fly.
sp.l: Either my eyes deceive me, or here comes
The form of Bellaflora.

sp.speaker: Bella.
sp.p: What do you gaze? Do you not know me Sir?

sp.speaker: Fly.
sp.p: Yes ſure, I know you; Are not you Bellaflora?

sp.speaker: Bella.
sp.p: That is my name.

sp.speaker: Fly.
sp.p: I know it is, but were not you diſguis'd, and call'd Fairchaſte?

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: I remember your amorous Alphabet.

sp.speaker: Fly.
sp.p: O my ſtrange excellent fortune; can you forgive all?

sp.speaker: Bella.
sp.p: Yes, and ſeal my ſelf thy own for ever.

sp.speaker: Wild.
sp.p: My dear Couſin.

sp.speaker: Bella.
sp.p: How Sir?

sp.speaker: Fly.
sp.p: Tis ſo indeed, the Wildblood's out, this is your couſin Worthlove.

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: Welcome from France good Couſin.

sp.speaker: Wild.
sp.p: Fair couſin I thank thee, this unity contents me.

sp.speaker: Riv.
sp.p: As I live here's Sir R. Lamard that broke the priſon, how the devil dares he venter.

sp.speaker: Sir Rev.
sp.p: Be your leave Zhentelmen, room for Sir Reveren. who be come to claim his Lady, his Madam.

sp.speaker: Nice.
sp.p: How came you out of priſon Sir.

sp.speaker: Sir Rev.
sp.p: Begar me pay de mony, and now me come to your dautera.

sp.speaker: Nice.
sp.p: Now you have paid away your mony, the truth is, Sir ſhe is diſpos'd of to another.

sp.speaker: Keep.
sp.p: And we'l diſpoſe of you that can break priſons.

sp.speaker: Sir Rev.
sp.p: Begar here be de Keeper, vat fall me do now?

sp.speaker: Pim.
sp.p: Nay, you'r faſt enough, we'l take an order for your ſliding.

sp.speaker: Sir Rev.
sp.p: Zhentelmen vill no man be my bayl?

sp.speaker: Nice.
sp.p: The ſum is too great for me.

sp.speaker: Sir Rev.
sp.p: Pray Zhentelmen.

sp.speaker: Fly.
sp.p: Not I.

sp.speaker: Rivers.
sp.p: Nor I.

sp.speaker: Wild.
sp.p: Nor I.

sp.speaker: Keep.
sp.p: Come Sir, you muſt to priſon agen.

sp.speaker: Sir Rev.
sp.p: Mus, begar me vill not.

sp.speaker: Pimpw.
sp.p: Then we muſt force you Sir.

sp.speaker: Sir Rev.
sp.l: You Pimping rogue, why do you tug me thus?
You know me well enough.

sp.speaker: Pim.
sp.p: What is your tongue chang'd, what tricks have you?

sp.speaker: Sir Rev.
sp.p: I'le ſpeak with Mr. Nice. Pray Sir, peruſe that Picture and Letter.

sp.speaker: Nice.
sp.p: 'Tis my wives picture ſure; Splendora, was not this your Mothers picture?

sp.speaker: Splend.
sp.p: Yes Sir, the very ſame ſhe gave my brother, when he went to Paris.

sp.speaker: Nice
sp.p: And this my hand, the Letter that I ſent him.

sp.speaker: Sir Rev.
sp.p: And I your ſon, come to crave a bleſſing.

sp.speaker: Nice.
sp.p: And with my heart thou haſt it.

sp.speaker: Sir Rev.
sp.p: Mr. Brooks your ſervant.

sp.speaker: Fly.
sp.p: Noble Mr. Nice.

sp.speaker: Sir Rev.
sp.p: Hah, my politick Stephen.

sp.speaker: Fly.
sp.p: No, my politick William.

sp.speaker: Wild.
sp.p: Sir I am yours, and joy to ſee you in England.

sp.speaker: Splend.
sp.p: Welcome to London brother, you can court a Lady moſt exactly in broken French.

sp.speaker: Sir Rev.
sp.p: I am glad it pleas'd you ſiſter; Keepers I'le quit you preſently, that Action which was entred was a plot of mine, to have my father match this Gentleman with my kind ſiſter; there's no danger in't I can aſſure you.

sp.speaker: Keep.
sp.p: Well, I'm contented Sir.

sp.speaker: Nice.
sp.p: You are wags I ſee; were you ſent ſeven years ago France, and come agen to cozen your friends, but Heaven be your joy. Come, cannot you expreſs a little of your French action with theſe Ladies, ſhall we not have a Dance?

sp.speaker: Fly.
sp.p: And very fit, methinks the time requires it.

sp.speaker: Rivers.
sp.p: With all my heart.

sp.speaker: Wild.
sp.p: And mine.

sp.speaker: Fly.
sp.p: Every man take his Lady then.

sp.speaker: Nice.
sp.p: Gentlemen, y'have done exceeding well; if you pleaſe to walk in, Dinner at this hour waits for you.

sp.speaker: Fly.
sp.p: Come my mad merry Mates and fellow-Travellers, let's in and chat the ſtory of our Travels, the tricks of our Diſguiſes, with the queint and jovial Humours which we have found ith' Compter.
sp.l: To marry and be civill our next care is,
We now have done enough for Youths Fegaries.

lg.l: WEll; How is't now? we heard you laugh, but pray.
Was it at us, the Poet, or the Play?
The Poet's full of joy though, to the brim,
And ſayes, he's ſure ye do not laugh at him;
Becauſe, he findes you onely laugh at that,
Which he deſires may be worth laughing at:
And then he heard you Clap; that Verdict ſtands
In Law, he hath it under all your hands;
Vnleſs when we were freed from Woodſtreet Den,
You had a plot to Clap us up agen:
But waving all, we (without more ſuſpence)
Accept your Clapping in the better ſenſe.
This is the ſum, I have no more to ſay,
Either for Poet, Actors, or the Play:
If his dull Humours pleaſe not, we implore,
That you'l go all toth' Compter and ſee more.

div.p: THis Comedy, called, The Walks of Iſling ton and Hogsdon, With the Humours of Woodſtreet-Compter, may be Acted: This 2. Auguſt, 1641.
